10' Pole.description: A 10-foot-long wooden pole, useful for prodding suspicious areas, triggering traps from a distance, or bridging small gaps. The pole is about 2 inches in diameter and sturdy enough to support a moderate amount of weight.
10' Pole.name: 10' Pole

Acrobatics.description: The character can perform impressive acrobatic feats, balance on ropes and wires, and so forth. A successful skill roll is required to perform any acrobatic feat; failure may result in the character falling. A successful roll allows the character to reduce the effective height of a fall by 10 feet. This skill also grants a +2 bonus on saves vs. mechanical traps where agility would help, such as tilting floors and pit traps.
Acrobatics.name: Acrobatics

Acting.description: The Acting skill enables a character to convincingly portray different personalities, emotions, or even other characters. It is used to deceive others, blend into a new role, or perform on stage. This skill can be crucial when impersonating someone or maintaining a disguise, and can also help in social situations where creating the right impression is essential.
Acting.name: Acting

Agate.description: An agate gem is a type of chalcedony known for its distinctive banding patterns and vibrant colors. It often features layers in hues like white, blue, red, or brown, and can have a polished surface with a smooth, glassy appearance. Agates are prized for their unique, natural beauty and are used in jewelry and decorative items.
Agate.name: Agate

Alchemy.description: This skill provides the ability to recognize and identify common alchemical substances, potions, and poisons. Success with this skill will allow a character to create an antidote potion for one specific type of poison—if the DM says that this is possible in his campaign.
Alchemy.name: Alchemy

Alertness.description: This skill allows the character to draw a weapon without losing any time, avoid the effects of surprise, and wake up at the slightest out-of-place noise.
Alertness.name: Alertness

Alternate Magics.description: This skill gives a character basic familiarity with magics that are not related to standard spellcasting. It includes knowing many magical abilities of well-known Prime Plane and extraplanar monsters and of Immortal beings. The DM defines what types of knowledge this skill provides in his or her campaign.
Alternate Magics.name: Alternate Magics

Amber.description: Amber is a gemstone with a warm, golden-orange hue, often containing natural inclusions or bubbles. It has a smooth, polished surface and a unique texture as it is formed from fossilized tree resin. Amber's rich color and transparency make it highly valued for jewelry and decorative items.
Amber.name: Amber

Amethyst.description: Amethyst is a purple variety of quartz known for its rich color and clarity. It often forms in clusters with pointed crystals and ranges in shade from light lavender to deep violet. Amethyst is popular in jewelry and is believed to have calming and healing properties.
Amethyst.name: Amethyst

Analyze.description:
This spell allows the caster to handle one item and learn about its enchantment. The caster must use the item correctly: helms must be worn, swords held, bracelets worn on the wrist, etc. Any consequences, such as from cursed or trapped items, will affect the caster as usual, with saving throws if applicable.

The caster has a 15% chance plus 5% per level to determine one magical property, or to confirm that the item is non-magical. The spell provides general information, such as whether a weapon’s bonus is “many” or “few,” and estimates the number of charges within 25% accuracy.
Analyze.name: Analyze

Animal Training (choose type).description: This skill allows the character to raise, train, and care for one specific type of animal. The animal can be taught simple tricks or basic commands. For each additional type of animal the character wishes to train, they must take this skill again. For example, horse training and dog training are separate skills, but a horse trainer can handle any horse or pony, and a dog trainer can train any breed of dog. This skill is commonly found in cultures with a strong bond to a specific animal type.
Animal Training (choose type).name: Animal Training (choose type)

Animate Dead.description:
This spell animates skeletons or zombies from normal skeletons or dead bodies within range. The animated undead creatures will follow the spellcaster's commands until destroyed by a cleric or a *Dispel Magic* spell.

Hit Dice: For each level of the caster, one Hit Die of undead may be animated. Skeletons have the same Hit Dice as the original creature, while zombies gain one extra Hit Die. Humans and demihumans are considered 1 HD creatures for this spell.

Animated undead cannot cast spells but are immune to sleep, charm effects, and poison.
Animate Dead.name: Animate Dead

Anti-Plant Shell.description:
This spell creates an invisible barrier around the druid's body (less than an inch away) that blocks all plant attacks and prevents damage from plant-like monsters.

Effect on Movement: While protected, the druid can push through dense growth, creating a path that others may follow. The barrier prevents the druid from physically attacking plants, though spells may still be cast against them.
Anti-Plant Shell.name: Anti-Plant Shell
Anti-Plant Shell.spellDuration: 1 round per level of the druid

Aquamarine.description: Aquamarine is a gemstone with a light blue color and a smooth, polished surface. It has a crystalline appearance that reflects light, showcasing its clarity and delicate hue. Often used in jewelry, aquamarine is valued for its brilliance and tranquil color.
Aquamarine.name: Aquamarine

Arrow (silver).description: An arrow made with a silver tip. This can be used to damage certain types of creatures like lycanthropes.
Arrow (silver).name: Arrow (silver)

Arrows.description: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.
Arrows.name: Arrows

Art (Choose Type).description: This skill covers the creation of art, such as painting, sculpture, woodcarving, or mosaic. The player must specify the type of art the character practices. A successful skill check allows the character to create works that can improve NPC reactions. For example, presenting a well-crafted portrait or sculpture to an NPC may provide a +2 bonus to reaction rolls. If preferred, the player can choose to base this skill on Wisdom instead of Intelligence.
Art (Choose Type).name: Art (Choose Type)

Art (choose type).description: This skill involves creating art, such as painting, sculpture, or woodcarving. The character must choose one form of art they specialize in, and can take this skill multiple times to learn different forms. Successful use of the skill can improve NPC reactions; for instance, presenting a portrait to an NPC can grant a +2 bonus to reaction rolls. The character can choose to base this skill on Wisdom instead of Intelligence.
Art (choose type).name: Art (choose type)

Artillery.description: This skill enables a character to command the crew of a piece of artillery, such as a catapult or trebuchet. While knowledge of the skill suffices for general operation, a skill check is required each time the artillery is aimed at a new target. This skill also allows the character to make precise calculations regarding trajectory, distance, and throw weight. It can be taken multiple times to learn both operation and construction of siege weapons. If an artillery device is improperly operated or built without a character possessing this skill, it is more prone to malfunction or failure.
Artillery.name: Artillery

Avenger.description:
A Chaotic traveling fighter can achieve the title of Avenger if they meet specific requirements. Fighters who do not meet these conditions may instead become knights (described separately).

  1. Fealty to a Clerical Order: To become a avenger, the fighter must swear an oath of service to a Chaotic clerical order. Only fighters of Name level or higher are eligible. Once accepted, the avenger is bound to serve the order and may be summoned by its leaders at any time to perform tasks that align with the powers of Evil.

  2. Detect Evil: A avenger can detect evil, as per the cleric spell, once per round by concentrating. This ability has a range of 120 feet but cannot be used in the same round as an attack.

  3. Cleric Spells: A avenger with a Wisdom score of 13 or higher can cast cleric spells as if they were a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 17th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 5th-level cleric.
  4. Fighters with Wisdom scores of 12 or less can still become avengers but cannot cast spells. Avengers are trained in meditation and spellcasting by the clerics of their order, who provide this service without accepting compensation.

  5. Turn Undead: Avengers can turn undead with the same ability as a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the avenger turns undead as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 16th or 17th level, the avenger turns undead as a 5th-level cleric.

  6. Hireling Limit: An avenger is prohibited from having human or demihuman hirelings. However, they are allowed to try and persuade Chaotic monsters to become their hirelings.

    • If a Chaotic creature is not immediately hostile, the avenger can offer food or treasure, signaling friendship through words or gestures.

    • If this approach fails, using threats or engaging in combat and achieving surrender might work similarly.

    • If the creature's Reaction roll results in friendship, it is convinced to follow and obey the avenger. This effect lasts as long as a charm spell cast by a magic-user; once it ends, it cannot be renewed.

    • The avenger can have as many Chaotic monster hirelings as their Charisma score permits; once one is lost, they may attempt to persuade another.

  7. Requesting Sanctuary:

    An avenger may approach any castle, ruin, or dungeon overseen by an intelligent Chaotic creature or individual, and using their alignment language, request Sanctuary (see knight, above). The avenger can also pose as a knight to seek Sanctuary from other rulers. If they successfully fool the ruler (and evade any magic that reveals alignment), the ruler will offer them standard Sanctuary.

Paladin / Avenger Turn Undead Table

SkeletonTDDDDDDD+

Haunt----------1197

Lich----------------
Special----------------

Legend:

  • 7, 9, 11: Roll 2d6 and meet or exceed this number to turn undead.
  • T: Automatically turn undead.
  • D: Automatically destroy undead.
  • D+: Automatically destroy [[/r 3d6 #Hit Dice]] Hit Dice of undead.
Avenger.name: Avenger

Backpack.description: A sturdy pack used to carry equipment on the character's back. The shoulder straps leave the character's hands free for other actions. It has a capacity of 400 coins.
Backpack.name: Backpack

Backstab.description: When attacking an unaware opponent from behind, a thief gains a +4 bonus to hit and deals double damage.
Backstab.name: Backstab

Banded Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of chain mail with horizontal metal strips fastened into the mail. Banded mail gives a character an armor class of 4. It doesn’t quite have the protection of plate mail, but is cheaper and lighter.
Banded Mail.name: Banded Mail

Bargaining.description: The Bargaining skill allows a character to negotiate favorable terms in transactions or agreements. It covers haggling over prices, making persuasive arguments in trade deals, and finding compromises that satisfy all parties. A successful Bargaining check can result in better prices, advantageous terms, or profitable contracts.
Bargaining.name: Bargaining

Bedroll.description: A heavy wooden blanket with a small pillow.
Bedroll.name: Bedroll

Bless*.description:
This spell enhances the morale of friendly creatures by +1 and grants them a +1 bonus to all attack and damage rolls. It affects only those within a 20' x 20' area and only those who are not yet engaged in melee combat.

The reversed form, blight, imposes a -1 penalty to morale, attack rolls, and damage rolls of enemies. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid these penalties.
Bless*.name: Bless*

Blight*.description:
Blight, imposes a -1 penalty to morale, attack rolls, and damage rolls of enemies. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid these penalties.

It affects only those within a 20' x 20' area and only those who are not yet engaged in melee combat.
Blight*.name: Blight*

Blind Shooting.description: This skill allows the character to shoot at a target without seeing it, typically used in darkness or when the target is outside the range of sight or infravision. The character must be able to hear the target to evaluate its position. A successful skill check allows a shot with no penalties due to darkness, though an attack roll is still required to hit the target.
Blind Shooting.name: Blind Shooting

Blowgun, Long.description:
This weapon is a tube that measures between 6 inches and 4 feet in length. The user inserts a small dart or thorn into the tube, aims it at a target, and blows air into it, propelling the dart toward the target. The darts themselves do not cause any damage; however, they are typically coated with poison. A blowgun dart only scratches the victim, resulting in minimal penetration and no significant harm. If struck, the victim must make a saving throw against poison or experience its effects. Depending on the victim's size or level of experience, they may receive a bonus to the saving throw (refer to the Weapon Special Effects Table). No undead creatures or any beings immune to poison can be affected by a blowgun.

Using lethal poison as a weapon is considered an immoral act. Due to its risks, local or regional authorities may outlaw poison, and in such cases, Lawful characters generally refrain from using it. The Dungeon Master (DM) may decide to prohibit player characters from utilizing poisons in their campaign. Players should be informed that if they choose to equip their characters with blowguns, they should expect that monsters will also possess them.

Longer blowguns require two hands to wield; therefore, the user cannot use a shield and will always lose individual initiative to characters wielding one-handed weapons. Halflings and small nonhumans, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.
Blowgun, Long.name: Blowgun, Long

Blowgun, Short.description:
This weapon is a tube that measures between 6 inches and 4 feet in length. The user inserts a small dart or thorn into the tube, aims it at a target, and blows air into it, propelling the dart toward the target. The darts themselves do not cause any damage; however, they are typically coated with poison. A blowgun dart only scratches the victim, resulting in minimal penetration and no significant harm. If struck, the victim must make a saving throw against poison or experience its effects. Depending on the victim's size or level of experience, they may receive a bonus to the saving throw (refer to the Weapon Special Effects Table). No undead creatures or any beings immune to poison can be affected by a blowgun.

Using lethal poison as a weapon is considered an immoral act. Due to its risks, local or regional authorities may outlaw poison, and in such cases, Lawful characters generally refrain from using it. The Dungeon Master (DM) may decide to prohibit player characters from utilizing poisons in their campaign. Players should be informed that if they choose to equip their characters with blowguns, they should expect that monsters will also possess them.

Longer blowguns require two hands to wield; therefore, the user cannot use a shield and will always lose individual initiative to characters wielding one-handed weapons. Halflings and small nonhumans, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.
Blowgun, Short.name: Blowgun, Short

Bravery.description: This skill allows the character to resist the effects of magical fear, as well as the results of morale checks or skills like Intimidation. NPCs using this skill can ignore fear effects with a successful skill check.
Bravery.name: Bravery

Call Lightning.description:
This spell allows the druid to call lightning bolts from a storm. A storm of any type must be present within 360' of the druid for the spell to work, though the druid need not be within the storm itself.

Effect: The druid may call 1 lightning bolt per turn, striking any target point within 360'. Each bolt affects an area 20' across. Creatures in this area take 8d6 (8-48) electrical damage, though they may make a saving throw vs. spells to take half damage.

The druid can call a bolt each turn as long as the storm or spell duration continues.
Call Lightning.name: Call Lightning
Call Lightning.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster
Call Lightning.spellEffect: Calls lightning bolts from a storm

Caltrops (bag of 20).description:
Small metal spikes sufficient to cover a 5’ square area. Creatures moving through the area have a 2-in-6 chance of treading on a spike. Victims suffer a 50% reduction of movement rate until they are healed.

Three uses max.
Caltrops (bag of 20).name: Caltrops (bag of 20)

Carbuncle.description: A carbuncle is not a specific gemstone but rather a term historically used to refer to any red gemstone, particularly a deep red garnet or ruby. It is characterized by its rich, dark red color and smooth, polished surface. Carbuncles were highly valued in ancient times for their striking appearance and were often set in jewelry and ceremonial objects.
Carbuncle.name: Carbuncle

Cause Critical Wounds*.description: This spell inflicts 3d6 + 3 points of damage on a creature touched by the caster. A successful melee attack roll is required.
Cause Critical Wounds*.name: Cause Critical Wounds*
Cause Critical Wounds*.spellEffect: Inflicts critical damage on one creature

Cause Disease*.description: Cause disease, infects the target with a wasting disease. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells or suffer a -2 penalty on attack rolls and hindered healing. The disease is fatal within [[/r 2d12 #Cure Disease duration in days]] days unless removed by a cure disease spell.
Cause Disease*.name: Cause Disease*

Cause Fear*.description: The reversed form of the spell, cause fear, will make any one creature flee for two turns. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect. This reversed spell has a range of 120'.
Cause Fear*.name: Cause Fear*

Cause Light Wounds*.description:
This spell cures one living (not undead or non-living) creature of [[/r 1d6+1 #Cure Light Wounds]] points of damage. The caster can cure themselves with this spell.

Alternately, the spell can be used to cure paralysis (except that caused by a Hold Person or Hold Monster spell), although if it does so then no damage will be cured at the same time.

The spell will not increase the target's maximum hit points.

When reversed, this spell, cause light wounds, causes [[/r 1d6+1 #Cause Light Wounds]] points of damage to the target. No saving throw is allowed, but the caster must make a normal attack roll to inflict this damage.
Cause Light Wounds*.name: Cause Light Wounds*

Cause Serious Wounds*.description: This spell inflicts 2d6 + 2 points of damage on a creature touched by the caster. A successful melee attack roll is required to deliver the spell.
Cause Serious Wounds*.name: Cause Serious Wounds*

Caving.description: The character with this skill always knows their location while exploring underground caves, caverns, and river systems. They automatically recall the route taken as long as they were conscious. This skill is especially useful for dwarves and can also help characters navigate mazes. If disoriented or forced to flee for a long distance, a skill check is required to avoid becoming lost.
Caving.name: Caving

Ceremony (choose specific Immortal).description: The character knows how to honor an Immortal through ritual and ceremony. This skill allows a cleric to perform normal rituals of their order and could permit a character to gain an Immortal's attention through devout prayer, fasting, or sacrifice. This skill includes knowledge of rituals pleasing to the Immortal.
Ceremony (choose specific Immortal).name: Ceremony (choose specific Immortal)

Cestus.description: The cestus (plural: cesti) is a type of glove or hand-wrap with rough, cutting edges on the back, designed to increase the damage of punching attacks. If the campaign includes the optional rules for using two weapons, a character does not incur the -4 penalty when using a cestus on their offhand.
Cestus.name: Cestus

Chain Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of small metal rings that are linked together to form a flexible protective material. Chain mail gives a character an armor class of 5.
Chain Mail.name: Chain Mail

Chain Mail +1.description: This is a suit primarily composed of small metal rings that are linked together to form a flexible protective material. Chain mail gives a character an armor class of 5.
Chain Mail +1.name: Chain Mail +1

Charm Monster.description:
This spell is identical in effect to the *Charm Person* spell but can affect any creature except an undead monster.

Multiple Targets: When cast on creatures with 3 Hit Dice or less, it charms 3d6 (3-18) creatures. For creatures with more than 3 Hit Dice, it affects only one target.

Each creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect.
Charm Monster.name: Charm Monster

Charm Person.description:
This spell affects humans, demihumans, and certain other creatures. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells; if failed, the target views the caster as a “best friend” and will defend them against any perceived threat. The spell does not affect animals, magical creatures, undead, or creatures larger than ogres.

The charmed creature obeys friendly commands but resists those that go against its nature or cause self-harm. The duration depends on the target’s Intelligence, allowing periodic saving throws:

  • High Intelligence (13-18): Save every day
  • Average Intelligence (9-12): Save every week
  • Low Intelligence (3-8): Save every month
Charm Person.name: Charm Person

Cheating.description: This is the skill of winning at gambling games by cheating, such as dealing cards from the bottom of the deck. A Cheating skill roll is made against each character being cheated. If any of them make a successful check against the cheater's roll, they detect the cheating. This skill is limited to characters of Chaotic alignment.
Cheating.name: Cheating

Chest (small strongbox).description:
Chests are reinforced wooden boxes with lids and sides that are made tight to prevent anything from getting out or into the box. The price is for a box with integrated lock and strong metal reinforcements.

Weight held (pounds/coins)200/2,000
Volume held (cu. ft.)2
Hardness/HP6/4
Chest (small strongbox).name: Chest (small strongbox)

Clairvoyance.description:
This spell allows the caster to see through the eyes of any single creature within 60'. Each turn, the caster can switch to another creature's eyes within range without needing to recast the spell.

Restrictions: The spell's effect is blocked by two feet of rock or a thin coating of lead. No saving throw applies.
Clairvoyance.name: Clairvoyance

Cleric.description:
A cleric is a human character devoted to a significant cause, such as serving an Immortal or embodying the ideals of their alignment. Clerics combine martial prowess with divine magic, using their faith and beliefs to heal, protect, and combat evil. They are restricted to blunt weapons like maces and staves, reflecting their spiritual focus.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Wisdom, granting an experience bonus for scores of 13 or higher.
  • Combat and Armor: Clerics can wear any armor and use shields, but they are limited to non-edged weapons.
  • Special Abilities: Clerics can turn undead, using their divine power to repel or destroy them. They begin casting clerical spells at 2nd level, focusing on healing, protection, and divination.
  • Experience Table: They advance steadily, gaining hit points and new spell slots with each level.

Advancement:

  • At 9th level, a cleric reaches "Name level" and is referred to as a patriarch or matriarch. They have the option to establish a stronghold, which can be a fortress or temple serving their clerical order.
  • Stronghold Details: Building a stronghold requires land, which is usually granted by their clerical hierarchy or local rulers. The cleric's order may subsidize construction costs, often covering up to 50%.
  • A stronghold attracts retainers: 1d6 x 50 loyal troops of the cleric’s alignment and 1d6 low-level clerics to assist with religious duties. These followers do not require pay and have high morale, reflecting their devotion.
  • Alternatively, a cleric may choose to remain a traveling cleric, free from the responsibilities of landownership, focusing on aiding others and spreading their faith through quests and adventures.

Clerics are pivotal in both spiritual and martial roles, capable of influencing the world through faith, leadership, and divine power. Their journey often balances personal growth, the needs of their order, and the demands of their adventuring life.
Cleric.name: Cleric

Climb Sheer Surface.description: The thief can climb steep surfaces, such as walls, cliffs, or even ceilings, with a base chance of success determined by their level.
Climb Sheer Surface.name: Climb Sheer Surface

Cloak, long.description: A long cloak to cover one's shoulders and back. Some have hoods. Prices can vary greatly depending on quality and ornateness.
Cloak, long.name: Cloak, long

Cloak, short.description: A short cloak to cover one's shoulders and back for warmth. Some have hoods. Prices can vary greatly depending on quality and ornateness.
Cloak, short.name: Cloak, short

Clothes, Fine.description: This set of clothing is made from the finest materials and often decorated with embroidery, jewelry, or other adornments. It is suitable for noble gatherings and other high-status occasions.
Clothes, Fine.name: Clothes, Fine

Clothes, Good.description: These are high-quality clothes, possibly adorned with minor decorative elements. They are suitable for attending social events and for characters wishing to make a good impression.
Clothes, Good.name: Clothes, Good

Clothes, Plain.description: A set of simple clothing such as a tunic and pants, a blouse and skirt, a dress, or a robe. Suitable for most travel and adventuring purposes. No special benefits provided.
Clothes, Plain.name: Clothes, Plain

Clothform.description:
This spell creates up to 30' x 30' of non-magical cloth in a single piece. The cloth is permanent and cannot be dispelled.

Shaping: If the caster has an appropriate Craft skill (or similar character background in campaigns without skills), they can shape the cloth during creation, forming objects like tents, sails, garments, or ropes. Unshaped cloth can be cut and fashioned later.

Properties: The cloth resembles tough, undyed linen. It can be created with an unfinished edge to seamlessly join additional cloth created by another *Clothform* spell, making it ideal for sails or large, rugged fabrics.

The cloth extrudes from the caster's hands along the ground, piling up against obstacles without pushing them. It cannot be created in a space occupied by another object or attached to anything except other *Clothform* cloth.

This spell is commonly used for quick shelters or creating rope in adventuring situations.
Clothform.name: Clothform

Cloudkill.description:
This spell creates a poisonous cloud, 30' wide and 20' tall, that appears next to the caster and moves at a rate of 60' (20' per round) in one direction. The cloud is heavier than air and will sink where possible, but it will dissipate when encountering trees or thick vegetation. In confined spaces, the cloud’s size may be limited.

Effects on Creatures: All living creatures within the cloud take 1 point of damage per round. Creatures with less than 5 Hit Dice must make a saving throw vs. poison or die.
Cloudkill.name: Cloudkill

Club.description: A club is a crude blunt weapon—often little more than a roughly shaped piece of wood—that can be used in one hand.
Club.name: Club

Combat Bonuses.description: Halflings gain a +1 bonus to all attack rolls when using missile weapons, a +1 bonus to individual initiative, and a -2 AC bonus when attacked by creatures larger than man-sized.
Combat Bonuses.name: Combat Bonuses

Commune.description:
This spell allows the cleric to ask three yes-or-no questions of the greater powers (such as forces of nature, greater spirits, or Immortals).

Usage: May only be used once per week. The DM may restrict this to once a month if overused. Once a year, the cleric may ask six questions, usually on a day significant to the powers questioned.
Commune.name: Commune

Confuse Alignment*.description:
Confuse alignment, lasts for one turn per level of the spellcaster and can be cast on a creature by touch. No saving throw is allowed. For the duration of the spell, any attempt to discern the recipient's alignment will yield a false result. This false alignment will remain consistent for all subsequent detection attempts during the spell's duration.

This spell allows the spellcaster to determine the alignment (Lawful, Neutral, or Chaotic) of any one creature within 10'. It can also reveal the alignment of an enchanted item or area, if applicable.
Confuse Alignment*.name: Confuse Alignment*

Confusion.description:
This spell causes confusion among creatures within a 30' radius (60' across). The spell affects 3-18 creatures in the area, with victims under 2 + 1 Hit Dice automatically failing their saves. Creatures with 2 + 1 or more Hit Dice can attempt a saving throw vs. spells each round they remain in the area to avoid confusion.

Effects of Confusion: Each round, the DM rolls [[/r 2d6 #confusion effect]] for each affected creature to determine its action, according to the table below:

Confusion Results

2d6 RollResult
2-5Attack the spellcaster's party
6-8Do nothing
9-12Attack the creature's own party
Confusion.name: Confusion

Conjure Elemental.description:
This spell allows the caster to summon one elemental (AC -2, HD 16, Damage 3d8) within range. The caster may only summon one elemental of each type (earth, air, fire, water) per day.

Control: The elemental will follow the caster's commands as long as concentration is maintained. The caster cannot fight, cast other spells, or move more than half speed while maintaining control. If control is lost, the elemental will attempt to kill the caster, attacking anyone in its path while pursuing.

The caster can dismiss a controlled elemental by concentration, while an uncontrolled elemental can be dismissed by a *Dispel Magic* or *Dispel Evil* spell.
Conjure Elemental.name: Conjure Elemental

Contact Outer Plane.description:
This spell allows the caster to contact an Immortal on an outer plane to seek answers to questions. However, contact with such powerful beings carries the risk of insanity. The caster can ask a number of questions equal to the “distance” to the outer plane.

Plane Distance and Insanity: “Distance” to a plane refers to the number of planes one would need to cross to reach it. The caster may choose the distance, up to the maximum, which affects the number of questions, chance of correct answers, and insanity risk. Higher-level casters (21st and above) reduce the insanity risk by 5% per level beyond 20.

If insanity does occur, the caster requires game-time rest equal to the plane’s number to recover.

Chance of Insanity and Knowledge

Distance & QuestionsChance of InsanityChance of KnowingChance of Lying*
35%25%50%
410%30%45%
515%35%40%
620%40%35%
725%50%30%
830%60%25%
935%70%20%
1040%80%15%
1145%90%10%
1250%95%5%

*The chance of lying also includes cases where the Immortal may not know the answer.

This spell can only be cast once per month.
Contact Outer Plane.name: Contact Outer Plane

Continual Darkness*.description: Continual darkness, creates a volume of complete darkness in a 30' radius. Torches, lanterns, and even a light spell will not affect it, and infravision cannot penetrate it. If cast on a creature's eyes, the creature must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded until the spell is removed. A continual light spell will cancel its effects.
Continual Darkness*.name: Continual Darkness*

Continual Light*.description:
This spell creates light as bright as daylight in a spherical volume with a 30' radius. It lasts until dispelled or countered by a continual darkness spell. Creatures that suffer penalties in bright daylight also suffer them within the area of effect.

If cast on a creature’s eyes, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded until the effect is removed. This spell can be cast in an area, on an object, or directly on a creature's eyes to cause blindness.

The reverse, continual darkness, creates a similarly-sized area of total darkness, unaffected by normal light sources and infravision. A continual light spell can cancel it. If cast on a creature’s eyes, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded.
Continual Light*.name: Continual Light*

Control Temperature 10' Radius.description:
This spell allows the druid to alter the temperature within a 10' radius (20' across) by up to 50 degrees Fahrenheit, either warming or cooling the air. The temperature changes instantly and remains as long as the druid maintains concentration and the spell's duration has not expired.

The effect moves with the druid, and the temperature can be adjusted by concentrating for one round. This spell is especially useful for surviving in extreme cold or heat.
Control Temperature 10' Radius.name: Control Temperature 10' Radius
Control Temperature 10' Radius.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Control Winds.description:
This spell allows the druid to control all air within range, causing it to increase to gale force or slow to dead calm as desired. The caster must concentrate for one full turn (without moving or attacking) to achieve a complete change in wind force.

Effect on Air Creatures: If the spell is directed at an air creature (like an air elemental), it may make a saving throw vs. spells. If it fails, the druid may slay or control the creature by manipulating the wind. The creature remains controlled as long as the druid concentrates and the spell remains active; if concentration is broken or the spell ends, the creature will turn hostile and attack the druid.

Countering: A higher-level spellcaster using *Control Winds* can easily counter this spell.
Control Winds.name: Control Winds
Control Winds.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster
Control Winds.spellRange: 10' radius per level of the caster

Coral.description: Coral is a gemstone known for its vibrant red or pink color. It has a smooth, polished surface with subtle natural patterns, reflecting its organic origin from marine life. Coral is often used in jewelry and decorative pieces for its unique texture and bold hue.
Coral.name: Coral

Craft.description: The Craft skill represents proficiency in a particular trade or profession, such as armor-making, bow-making, leatherworking, or weapon-smithing. The player must specify the type of craft the character knows when this skill is chosen. A successful roll allows the character to produce high-quality goods, make expert opinions, and even identify the craftsmanship of other items within the chosen craft. Multiple types of Craft skills can be taken, with each representing a different trade. This skill is essential for characters wishing to create or repair equipment and items within their area of expertise.
Craft.name: Craft

Create Air.description:
This spell provides breathable air in a volume of 8,000 cubic feet (such as a 20' x 20' x 20' room) for 1 hour per caster level.

Stationary Use: Typically cast in enclosed spaces, it remains in one area, providing air for all within.

Mobile Use: The spell can be cast on enclosed vehicles, living creatures, or items to travel with them, including underwater or in airless environments. For example, a pegasus-rider could cast it on themselves and their mount to travel into outer space. Stealthy movement underwater is impossible due to visible air bubbles.

The spell does not protect against poison gases unless the gas is a natural atmospheric component.
Create Air.name: Create Air

Create Food.description:
This spell creates enough food to feed up to 12 men and their mounts for one day. For every level above 8th, it creates enough for 12 more people and mounts.

Note: Created food spoils after 24 hours and cannot be stored for future use.
Create Food.name: Create Food

Create Magic Items.description: Starting at 9th level, a Magic-User can create permanent magical items such as potions, scrolls, and weapons. This process requires a high-level laboratory, special ingredients, and a significant amount of time and gold.
Create Magic Items.name: Create Magic Items

Create Poison*.description:
This spell creates poison in a creature or container upon touch. A creature must succeed on a saving throw vs. poison or die instantly. When cast on a container, the poison affects its contents with no save.

Notes: Poisoning is usually considered a Chaotic act.
Create Poison*.name: Create Poison*
Create Poison*.spellEffect: Creates poison in a creature or container

Create Water.description:
This spell summons an enchanted spring from the ground or a wall, flowing for 6 turns and producing enough water for 12 men and their mounts (about 50 gallons).

Each level above 8th allows the cleric to create water for an additional 12 men and mounts. The caster can control the amount of water produced, up to the spell’s maximum.
Create Water.name: Create Water

Crossbow, Hvy.description:
Here’s a rephrased description:

This is a ranged weapon consisting of a sturdy bow (like a short bow but smaller and sometimes made of metal) mounted horizontally across a stock with a trigger mechanism. It fires short bolts known as quarrels.

Heavy crossbows are cumbersome, requiring two hands to operate and slow to reload. A character with 18 strength can draw the string back single-handedly, allowing them to fire each round. Characters with less strength must place the crossbow on the ground, brace it with a foot, and use both hands to pull the string back, limiting them to firing every two rounds.

This crossbow requires both hands, so the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to opponents using one-handed weapons. Small creatures, such as halflings and goblins, cannot use this weapon.
Crossbow, Hvy.name: Crossbow, Hvy

Crossbow, Lt.description:
This weapon resembles the heavy crossbow but is smaller in size. It requires two hands to load, though only one hand is needed to fire.

This crossbow is a two-handed weapon; the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters using one-handed weapons. Halflings and small races, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.
Crossbow, Lt.name: Crossbow, Lt

Crystal.description: A crystal gemstone is typically transparent, showcasing a clear and faceted structure that reflects light, creating a sparkling effect. Its clarity and sharp edges make it highly valued for its brilliance and aesthetic appeal, commonly used in jewelry and decorative items.
Crystal.name: Crystal

Cure Blindness.description: This spell cures almost any form of blindness, including those caused by light or darkness spells. It will not affect blindness caused by a curse.
Cure Blindness.name: Cure Blindness

Cure Critical Wounds*.description: This spell heals one living creature of 3d6 + 3 points of damage.
Cure Critical Wounds*.name: Cure Critical Wounds*

Cure Disease*.description:
This spell cures any disease, including those caused by mummies or green slime. At 11th level or higher, it can also cure lycanthropy.

The reverse, cause disease, infects the target with a wasting disease. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells or suffer a -2 penalty on attack rolls and hindered healing. The disease is fatal within [[/r 2d12 #Cure Disease duration in days]] days unless removed by a cure disease spell.
Cure Disease*.name: Cure Disease*

Cure Light Wounds*.description:
This spell cures one living (not undead or non-living) creature of [[/r 1d6+1 #Cure Light Wounds]] points of damage. The caster can cure themselves with this spell.

Alternately, the spell can be used to cure paralysis (except that caused by a Hold Person or Hold Monster spell), although if it does so then no damage will be cured at the same time.

The spell will not increase the target's maximum hit points.

When reversed, this spell, cause light wounds, causes [[/r 1d6+1 #Cause Light Wounds]] points of damage to the target. No saving throw is allowed, but the caster must make a normal attack roll to inflict this damage.
Cure Light Wounds*.name: Cure Light Wounds*

Cure Serious Wounds*.description: This spell heals 2d6 + 2 points of damage on one living creature when touched by the caster.
Cure Serious Wounds*.name: Cure Serious Wounds*

Curse*.description:
This spell imposes a misfortune or penalty on the target. Curses are limited only by the caster's imagination but should be balanced to avoid backfiring on the caster at the DM's discretion.

Typical curse effects include a -4 penalty on attack rolls, -2 on saving throws, or a halved prime requisite. The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the curse.
Curse*.name: Curse*
Curse*.spellEffect: Inflicts a curse on one target

Dagger.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon.
Dagger.name: Dagger

Dagger +1.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon.
Dagger +1.name: Dagger +1

Dagger, Silver.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon. Because it is made of silver, this weapon can be used to damage certain magical creatures, such as Lycanthropes.
Dagger, Silver.name: Dagger, Silver

Danger Sense.description: A successful skill roll allows the character to detect imminent danger. The nature or source of the danger is not revealed, and the DM rolls in secret. The player is only informed if the roll is a success and danger is present.
Danger Sense.name: Danger Sense

Darkness*.description: Darkness, creates a 30' diameter circle of darkness that blocks all sight except infravision. Darkness can counter light and vice-versa. If cast at a creature’s eyes, the target must save vs. spells or be blinded until the effect ends.
Darkness*.name: Darkness*

Deception.description: The Deception skill enables a character to lie convincingly, mislead others, and create believable falsehoods. It is used to conceal intentions, bluff, or forge information. This skill can be vital for characters trying to hide the truth or manipulate others' perceptions in various social or investigative situations.
Deception.name: Deception

Detect Danger.description:
This spell allows the caster to sense hazards by concentrating on places, objects, or creatures within range. The caster needs a full round of concentration to examine one square foot of area, one creature, or one small object. Larger objects require more time.

After examination, the caster knows if the target is immediately dangerous, potentially dangerous, or benign, from the caster's point of view. The spell can detect poisons, which other spells might not. The duration is one hour in natural outdoor settings on the Prime Plane; elsewhere, it lasts for only three turns.
Detect Danger.name: Detect Danger

Detect Deception.description: The character can recognize deceptive behavior in an NPC. This skill does not reveal the truth of specific statements, motivations, or the exact nature of the deception. It only warns the character to distrust the deceptive NPC. The DM rolls secretly, informing the character only if successful. This skill does not work on player characters.
Detect Deception.name: Detect Deception

Detect Evil.description: When the spell is cast, the caster will see evilly enchanted objects within 120' glow dark red. It also causes creates that intent to harm the caster to glow when they are within the area of effect. Not all Chaotic alignment creatures will have evil intentions, but many do. Traps and poisons are neither good nor evil, merely dangerous; this spell does not reveal them.
Detect Evil.name: Detect Evil

Detect Invisible.description: This spell enables the spellcaster to see all invisible creatures and objects within range. The range is 10' for each level of the spellcaster. For example, a 3rd level spellcaster can use this spell to see invisible things within 30'.
Detect Invisible.name: Detect Invisible

Detect Magic.description:
This spell allows the caster to see a glow around any magical creature, object and place within range. Magical creatures do not get a saving throw against this effect.

The glow only extends a couple of inches around the magical object, so if it is in a container or behind another object then some or all of the glow may not be visible.
Detect Magic.name: Detect Magic

Detect Secret Door.description:
To detect a secret door, a character must specify the exact area being searched. The process typically takes one turn (10 minutes) for each 10-foot section of wall, floor, or ceiling. Elves, due to their keen sight, are given a bonus of 1 to their roll.
Either the Dungeon Master should roll or the roll should be blind, regardless of whether a secret door is present, to maintain player uncertainty. Once found, the location of the secret door can be noted, allowing future discovery without a roll.
Detect Secret Door.name: Detect Secret Door

Detection Skills.description: Dwarves can detect traps, sliding walls, sloping corridors, and new construction with a 1 in 3 chance. To search, the dwarf must actively look for these features, and the DM rolls 1d6; a roll of 1 or 2 indicates success.
Detection Skills.name: Detection Skills

Detection of Secret Doors.description: Elves have a 1 in 3 chance to detect secret and hidden doors when actively searching for them due to their keen sight.
Detection of Secret Doors.name: Detection of Secret Doors

Diamond.description: A diamond is a gemstone known for its clear and transparent appearance. It has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted design that enhances its brilliance and reflective properties. Diamonds are highly valued for their unmatched sparkle and elegance, making them a popular choice in jewelry.
Diamond.name: Diamond

Dimension Door.description:
This spell transports one creature (either the caster or a target within 10') to a location up to 360' away. The caster specifies the destination, either by choosing a known location or by stating the direction and distance (up to a maximum of 360').

Destination: If the specified location is occupied by a solid object, the spell fails with no effect.

Saving Throw: An unwilling target can make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being transported.
Dimension Door.name: Dimension Door

Disarm.description:
This is a Fighter Combat Option maneuver available to fighters and mystics starting at 9th level, and to demihumans at different experience levels (see their experience tables). It can only be used when attacking an opponent armed with a weapon. The fighter applies their usual Strength and magic bonuses to the attack roll. If the attack hits, no damage is dealt. Instead, the opponent rolls 1d20, subtracts their Dexterity bonuses, and adds the fighter’s Dexterity bonuses. If the final result exceeds the opponent's Dexterity score, they drop their weapon.

For example, Sir Hogier faces a warrior he wishes to capture alive. The warrior has AC 0 and a Dexterity of 13. Sir Hogier, a 20th-level fighter, has a Strength of 16 and wields a +2 sword, giving him a +4 to attack rolls. His Dexterity is 12, with no bonus. Sir Hogier needs a 7 to hit AC 0. He rolls a 6, adding his +4 bonus to make a total of 10, successfully hitting the warrior.

The warrior then rolls 1d20 and gets a 15. Subtracting his Dexterity bonus of +1 (from his Dexterity of 13) results in 14. Since Sir Hogier has no Dexterity bonus, the final roll remains 14, which is greater than the warrior’s Dexterity score of 13. The disarm attempt succeeds.

Once disarmed, the opponent can either switch weapons, losing initiative for the next round, or attempt to retrieve the dropped weapon. To retrieve it, the opponent must retreat and pick up the weapon.
Disarm.name: Disarm

Disguise.description: The Disguise skill allows a character to alter their appearance convincingly to impersonate someone else. This requires a successful skill roll for each individual or group the character attempts to deceive. Targets of the disguise must make a Wisdom check against the character's Disguise roll to see through the impersonation. This skill is invaluable for covert operations, espionage, and any situation where a character must appear as someone else. A failure may result in the disguise being detected, exposing the character to potential danger or hostility.
Disguise.name: Disguise

Dispel Evil.description:
This spell affects all undead and enchanted monsters within 30'. Each affected creature must make a saving throw vs. spells or be destroyed. If cast on a single creature, it takes a -2 penalty to its saving throw.

Effect: Banishes creatures from other planes if they fail their saving throw. Those that save must flee and stay away as long as the caster concentrates, remaining stationary.

The spell can also remove a curse from one item or dispel a magical charm effect on a creature.
Dispel Evil.name: Dispel Evil
Dispel Evil.spellEffect: Affects undead, enchanted creatures, or one curse or charm

Dispel Magic.description:
This spell destroys other spell effects within a 20' x 20' x 20' area. It does not affect magical items but can cancel temporary effects they produce.

Effect: Automatically dispels spells from casters of equal or lower level. For higher-level casters, there is a 5% chance of failure per level difference.

Examples: A 7th-level caster trying to dispel a spell from a 9th-level caster has a 10% chance of failure.
Dispel Magic.name: Dispel Magic

Dissolve.description:
This spell turns soil or rock (but not constructed materials) within 240' into mud, affecting an area up to 3,000 square feet and up to 10' deep. The caster can determine the shape of the area within these limits (e.g., 20' x 150', 30' x 100').

Movement Effects: Creatures moving through the mud are slowed to 10% of their normal speed and may become stuck. At the DM's discretion, creatures in the area may need to make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being stuck.

Duration: The effect lasts for [[/r 3d6 #days]] 3-18 days.
Dissolve.name: Dissolve

Dissolve*.description:
This spell turns soil or rock (but not constructed materials) within 120' into mud. The affected area may be up to 3,000 square feet in surface area and 10' deep. The caster can shape the area within these limits (e.g., 20' x 150', 30' x 100').

Movement Effects: Creatures moving through the mud are slowed to 10% of their normal speed and may become stuck. A saving throw vs. spells may be required to avoid being stuck, at the DM's discretion.

Duration: The effect lasts for 3-18 days [[/r 3d6 #days]].
Dissolve*.name: Dissolve*

Divine Intervention.description: In dire situations, a high-level cleric may call upon their deity for direct intervention. This ability is used sparingly and typically involves a significant act of faith or sacrifice. The exact effects and likelihood of success are determined by the DM.
Divine Intervention.name: Divine Intervention

Druid.description:
A druid is a Neutral-aligned cleric who dedicates themselves to preserving and balancing nature, transitioning from traditional clerical duties upon reaching 9th level. To become a druid, a cleric must spend 1–4 months meditating in a woodland home under the guidance of a higher-level druid. Druids emphasize harmony with nature and avoid spells or actions tied to Good or Evil.

Druids have several distinct characteristics:

  • Armor and Weapons: They cannot use metal items, relying on leather armor, wooden shields, and non-metal, non-piercing weapons like staves.
  • Living and Philosophy: Druids must live in a natural setting, caring for and protecting a specific woodland area. They view themselves as stewards of nature, punishing deliberate harm while tolerating minor, necessary disruptions.
  • Spells: Druids can cast clerical spells along with a unique set of nature-oriented spells, including abilities to control plants, predict weather, and summon animals.
  • Advancement: Higher-level druids must challenge and defeat others of equal rank to advance, with only one "Great Druid" existing at the 36th level.

Druids blend magical abilities with a deep commitment to the balance and protection of nature.
Druid.name: Druid

Dwarf.description:
A dwarf is a sturdy, short-statured demi-human standing about 4 feet tall and weighing approximately 150 pounds. Known for their resilience and practicality, dwarves are experts in mining, construction, and combat. They often form close-knit clans and value craftsmanship and treasure.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Strength, granting experience bonuses for high scores (5% for a score of 13–15, 10% for 16 or higher). A Constitution score of 9 is required to play a dwarf.
  • Combat Abilities: Dwarves are skilled fighters, able to wield small and medium-sized weapons and use shields. They gain access to Fighter Combat Options, including advanced maneuvers like multiple attacks at higher levels.
  • Armor and Weapons: They can wear any armor but are restricted from using longbows or large melee weapons.

  • Special Abilities:

    • Infravision: Dwarves can see up to 60 feet in the dark.
    • Stonework Detection: Their expertise allows them to detect traps, sliding walls, sloping passages, and new construction with a 1–2 roll on a d6.
    • Magic Resistance: As they gain experience, dwarves take reduced damage from spells and magical effects.

Advancement:

  • Dwarves can progress to a maximum of 12th level.
  • Upon reaching 9th level, a dwarf may establish a stronghold in the wilderness. These are typically underground and located in hills or mountains, reflecting their cultural heritage.
  • The stronghold attracts a community of loyal dwarves (up to 200), including skilled craftsmen, warriors, and other retainers, creating a self-sustaining settlement.

Dwarves are resilient and resourceful adventurers, excelling in combat and defensive roles while contributing practical skills and unparalleled durability to any group.
Dwarf.name: Dwarf

ESP*.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to "hear" thoughts. The caster must concentrate in one direction for six rounds (one minute) to hear the thoughts (if any) of a creature within range. The spell allows the caster to understand the thoughts of any single living creature, regardless of language. It does not allow the caster to hear the thoughts of undead creatures.

If more than one creature is within range and in the direction the caster is concentrating, the spellcaster will "hear" a confused jumble of thoughts. The caster can sort out the jumble only by concentrating for an extra six rounds to find a single creature.

ESP is not hindered by any amount of wood or liquid and will penetrate up to two feet of rock, but a thin coating of lead will block the spell. Targets can make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effects.

The reverse of this spell, mindmask, may be cast by touch on any one creature. The recipient is completely immune to ESP and all other forms of mind-reading for the spell's duration.
ESP*.name: ESP*

Elf.description:
Elves are slender, graceful demi-humans with delicate features and pointed ears. They typically stand between 5 and 5½ feet tall and weigh around 120 pounds. As a blend of fighters and magic-users, elves are skilled in combat and capable of casting spells, making them versatile and powerful adventurers.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisites: Strength and Intelligence. If both scores are 13 or higher, the elf gains a 5% experience bonus. If Intelligence is 16 or greater, this bonus increases to 10%.
  • Combat and Spellcasting: Elves can use all types of armor and weapons while also casting magic-user spells. They are particularly effective in combat when uninjured and can utilize both fighting and magical strategies.
  • Hit Dice: Elves roll 1d6 per level for hit points, with a maximum level of 10. They gain an additional +2 hit points at 10th level.

  • Special Abilities:

    • Infravision allows them to see up to 60 feet in the dark.
    • A natural immunity to ghoul paralysis.
    • They excel at finding secret doors, succeeding on a 1 or 2 when rolling a d6.
    • Elves gain resistance to dragon breath attacks at higher experience levels, taking half or one-quarter damage depending on their saving throw success.

Advancement and Strongholds:

Elves reach Name level at 9th level and may establish a stronghold in a natural, beautiful location, such as atop great trees or near waterfalls. These strongholds foster harmony with nearby animals, enabling communication and mutual protection. Elves can only advance to 10th level, but their combination of skills and magical abilities balances this limitation.

Their dual nature as fighters and magic-users makes elves both formidable allies and dangerous foes in any adventure.
Elf.name: Elf

Emerald.description: Emerald is a gemstone known for its rich green color and vibrant hue. It typically has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted appearance, enhancing its brilliance and clarity. Highly valued in jewelry, emeralds are prized for their striking beauty and elegance.
Emerald.name: Emerald

Endurance.description: The Endurance skill allows a character to perform strenuous activities over extended periods without succumbing to fatigue or exhaustion. It covers activities such as running, swimming, or marching for long distances, as well as withstanding harsh environmental conditions like extreme heat or cold. A successful Endurance check may be required to avoid penalties from prolonged exertion or to maintain performance in challenging circumstances.
Endurance.name: Endurance

Engineering.description: This skill covers the planning, design, and construction of large-scale projects like buildings, bridges, and dams. A character with this skill can oversee such projects to ensure they are structurally sound and meet the desired specifications. The skill can also be used to assess the stability and integrity of existing structures, determining their age, origin, and current condition. Without proper engineering oversight, large projects may collapse or otherwise fail catastrophically. In certain situations, the skill may also be applied to analyze and solve complex mechanical problems or to disable traps and devices constructed with advanced engineering.
Engineering.name: Engineering

Entangle.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to use any rope-like object of living or once-living material (roots, vines, leather ropes, plant-fiber ropes, etc.) to behave as they order. About 50' of normal 1/2" diameter vine plus 5' per level of the caster can be affected.

The commands which can be given during an entangle spell include: coil (form a neat stack), coil and knot, loop, loop and knot, tie and knot, and the reverses of all the above. The vine or rope must be within 1' of any object it is to coil around or tie up, so it often must be thrown at the target. This spell is very useful in climbing situations; a spellcaster can toss a rope up the side of a wall or cliff and command it to loop and knot itself around a projection at the height of the throw. Coil and knot effectively ties up a victim.

A person or monster attacked by any use of the spell may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effects of the entangle.
Entangle.name: Entangle

Escape.description: The Escape skill allows a character to slip free from bonds, such as ropes or manacles, and to break out of physical restraints or confined spaces. Success may depend on the quality of the bindings and the character’s current condition. This skill is also used to evade grapples and similar situations in combat.
Escape.name: Escape

Exorcism.description: Exorcism is a special ritual that high-level clerics (9th level or above) can perform to drive out possessing entities or malevolent spirits from a creature or location. The cleric must perform the ritual for a specified duration, and success depends on the cleric's level and the strength of the spirit.
Exorcism.name: Exorcism

Faerie Fire.description:
This spell outlines one or more creatures or objects with a pale, flickering, greenish fire, which does not cause damage. The outlined creatures or objects become more visible, granting a +2 bonus to attack rolls against them. The druid can outline one man-sized creature for each 5 levels of experience, up to a maximum of 48 feet of fire at 20th level.

The objects or creatures need only be detected in some way (such as by sight, or a detect invisible spell) to be the object of this spell.
Faerie Fire.name: Faerie Fire

Feeblemind.description:
This spell affects only magic-users, elves, or other creatures capable of casting magical spells (excluding cleric and druid casters). The target's Intelligence is reduced to 2, rendering them helpless and unable to cast spells or think clearly.

Saving Throw: The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells, with a -4 penalty, to resist the effect. The feeblemind effect lasts until removed by a *Dispel Magic* or *Cureall* spell.
Feeblemind.name: Feeblemind

Fighter.description:
A fighter is a human whose primary focus is martial combat. Renowned for their strength and endurance, fighters excel in melee and ranged combat, often taking the lead in battle to protect their allies. They have the highest hit points among classes, enabling them to withstand significant damage.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Strength, granting experience bonuses for high scores (5% for 13–15, 10% for 16–18).
  • Combat Prowess: Fighters can use any weapon and wear any type of armor, including shields. They are also adept in specialized maneuvers like Lance Attack and Set Spear vs. Charge.
  • Hit Dice: Fighters roll a d8 for hit points at each level up to the 9th. Beyond that, they gain a fixed 2 hit points per level.
  • Maximum Level: 36th.

Advancement:

At 9th level, fighters achieve Name level and may choose one of two paths:

  • Land-Owning Fighter: Fighters can petition a ruler for land, often gaining the title of Baron (or equivalent). With their stronghold established, they attract up to 50 loyal fighters (levels 1–3) as retainers. In times of war, they may offer military aid to their ruler and receive assistance if their lands are threatened.
  • Traveling Fighter: These fighters eschew land ownership for a life of adventure. Depending on their alignment, they may adopt roles such as knights or paladins, gaining unique abilities like turning undead or detecting evil.

Stronghold Details:

Fighters who build a stronghold must secure land either by petitioning a ruler, claiming wilderness territory, or purchasing land. As rulers, they manage their dominion, attract settlers, and lead their men-at-arms in defense or expansion of their holdings. Titles can grow with their dominion's success, from Baron to Duke and beyond.

Fighters are essential to any adventuring party for their durability and combat capabilities, serving as the backbone of both offense and defense. They excel in both leadership roles and frontline combat, making them versatile and resilient characters.
Fighter.name: Fighter

Fighter Combat Options.description: At 900,000 XP, halflings gain access to Fighter Combat Options, including multiple attacks and advanced maneuvers such as Smash and Parry.
Fighter Combat Options.name: Fighter Combat Options

Find Trap.description: To search for traps, the player must specify the exact area they are examining, such as a 20-foot square room or a 20-foot corridor. Searching takes one turn (10 minutes) per area, and the Dungeon Master rolls to determine success. Thieves have a percentage-based chance to detect traps, determined by their level, while dwarves have a superior chance to locate large mechanical traps, such as pit traps, due to their natural affinity with stonework. The DM may modify the difficulty for especially hidden traps. Non-thief characters generally cannot detect traps unless their presence is obvious​​.
Find Trap.name: Find Trap

Find Traps.description: This spell causes all mechanical and magical traps within 30' of the spellcaster to emit a faint blue glow. While it reveals the presence of traps, it does not provide information on their type or how to disarm them. Ambushes or natural hazards like quicksand are not considered traps and will not be revealed by this spell.
Find Traps.name: Find Traps

Finger of Death*.description:
The reversed form of *Raise Dead*, this spell creates a death ray that kills a single living creature within 60' unless the target succeeds on a saving throw vs. death ray.

Undead Effect: If cast on an undead creature with 10 or more Hit Dice (such as a phantom, haunt, spirit, nightshade, or special), it restores 3d10 hit points instead of dealing damage.

A Lawful cleric will typically only use *Finger of Death* in life-or-death situations.
Finger of Death*.name: Finger of Death*
Finger of Death*.spellEffect: Kills one living creature or heals high-HD undead

Fire-Building.description: This skill allows a character to start a fire without using a tinderbox. A character with a tinderbox and this skill can automatically start fires under ordinary conditions. Without a tinderbox, the character must make a skill check each round, igniting the fire on a 1 or 2 on a 1d6 roll. Adverse conditions, such as high winds or wet wood, require a skill check with penalties as determined by the DM.
Fire-Building.name: Fire-Building

Fireball.description:
This spell creates a missile of fire that explodes into a 40' diameter (20' radius) fireball where it strikes. It deals 1d6 fire damage per caster level to every creature in the area.

Saving Throw: Each creature can make a saving throw vs. spells for half damage.

For example, a fireball cast by a 6th-level caster deals 6d6 (6-36) points of damage. On a successful saving throw, the damage is halved.
Fireball.name: Fireball

Floating Disc.description: This spell creates an invisible, horizontal disc capable of carrying up to 5000 cn (500 lbs). The disc remains at the caster's waist height and follows them, staying within 6' at all times. It cannot be used as a weapon or pass through obstacles. When the spell ends, the disc disappears, dropping anything it carried.
Floating Disc.name: Floating Disc

Fly.description:
This spell grants the target (including the caster, if desired) the ability to fly at will for a duration of 1d6 turns plus an additional turn per caster level.

The target can move at speeds up to 360' (120') by concentrating and can hover without concentration. Flight can be in any direction.
Fly.name: Fly

Food Tasting.description: The Food Tasting skill provides a character with the ability to detect subtle flavors and potential poisons in food and drink. It can be used to identify the quality and freshness of ingredients or to recognize dangerous substances that might otherwise go unnoticed. A successful check may reveal whether a dish has been tampered with or if it contains any harmful elements. This skill is particularly useful for adventurers wary of sabotage or treachery.
Food Tasting.name: Food Tasting

Free Monster*.description: This spell removes the paralysis effect from up to four creatures affected by *Hold Person* or *Hold Monster*. It has no other effects.
Free Monster*.name: Free Monster*

Free Person*.description: The reverse of *Hold Person*, this spell releases the paralysis of up to four victims of *Hold Person* (including *Hold Person* cast by a cleric). It has no effect on paralysis caused by other sources, such as a ghoul's paralyzing touch.
Free Person*.name: Free Person*
Free Person*.spellEffect: Removes paralysis from up to 4 creatures

Gambling.description: This skill is the ability to win money in games of skill (competitive card games, for example) and betting. It covers honest games only. A successful check increases the character's chances of winning money at these games.
Gambling.name: Gambling

Garlic.description: This aromatic herb is known to repel vampires and some other undead creatures. It is often used by adventurers as a protective measure when facing such enemies.
Garlic.name: Garlic

Garnet.description: Garnet is a gemstone known for its deep red color and glassy appearance. It has a smooth, polished surface that reflects light, showcasing its rich hue and clarity. Garnet is often used in jewelry for its brilliance and vibrant color.
Garnet.name: Garnet

Grappling Hook.description: A large 3- or 4-pronged hook made of specially hardened iron, used to anchor a rope. It can be thrown to hook onto surfaces, allowing the user to climb otherwise inaccessible areas. A successful attack roll is needed to secure it properly.
Grappling Hook.name: Grappling Hook

Growth of Animal.description: This spell doubles the size of one normal or giant animal, increasing its strength, damage, and carrying capacity accordingly. The animal’s behavior, armor class, and hit points remain unchanged, and the spell has no effect on intelligent or fantastic creatures.
Growth of Animal.name: Growth of Animal
Growth of Animal.spellEffect: Doubles the size of one animal

Growth of Plants*.description:
This spell causes normal brush or woods to grow densely with vines, creepers, thorns, or similar plant life appropriate to the area. The spell affects up to 3,000 square feet, with dimensions chosen by the caster, and all plants must be entirely within 120' of the caster.

Effect: The overgrown area becomes impassable to creatures except for those of giant size. The effect remains until removed by the reverse of the spell or by a *Dispel Magic* spell.

Reverse Spell - Shrink Plants: The reversed form, *Shrink Plants*, reduces all normal plants within the affected area to a passable state, negating the effect of *Growth of Plants*. It does not affect plant-like monsters, such as treants.
Growth of Plants*.name: Growth of Plants*

Half Damage from Dragon Breath.description: At 1,600,000 XP, an elf takes only half damage from dragon breath. A successful saving throw reduces the damage to one-quarter.
Half Damage from Dragon Breath.name: Half Damage from Dragon Breath

Halfling.description:
A halfling is a small, childlike demi-human standing about 3 feet tall and weighing around 60 pounds. Known for their love of comfort and community, halflings are woodland folk who excel in outdoor abilities and camaraderie with elves and dwarves. Despite their size, they are resourceful and capable combatants.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisites: Strength and Dexterity, granting an experience bonus (5% for either score of 13 or higher, 10% for both).

  • Abilities:

    • Halflings receive a +2 bonus to AC against larger creatures, a +1 bonus to attack rolls with missile weapons, and a +1 bonus to individual initiative.
    • They have a 90% chance to hide in woodlands and a 33% chance to hide in shadows within buildings or dungeons, provided they remain motionless.
  • Weapons and Armor: Halflings may use any small-sized weapons (e.g., short swords, daggers) and wear any armor specifically tailored to their size. Shields are allowed.
  • Combat Skills: They gain access to fighter combat options, including multiple attacks at higher levels.

Advancement:

  • Halflings can advance to a maximum of 8th level, gaining the title "Sheriff" upon reaching this level.
  • As they progress, halflings develop enhanced resistances, such as taking half damage from spells and breath weapons at high experience thresholds.

Strongholds:

  • Halflings can construct strongholds at any level if they have the resources. A stronghold often attracts a community of other halflings, creating a new settlement or shire.
  • These strongholds are typically located in tranquil, scenic areas like rolling hills or near streams, reflecting their preference for a peaceful lifestyle.

Halflings balance their physical limitations with their keen abilities and resilience, making them adaptable and valuable members of any adventuring party.
Halfling.name: Halfling

Hallucinatory Terrain.description:
This spell creates an illusion of a terrain feature, either indoors or outdoors, to hide or mimic terrain. The caster could create an illusory terrain over pits or quicksand, or a forest around a camp.

Area: The spell affects up to a 240' radius, and the caster may choose a smaller area, such as a room or a specific feature. For larger areas (such as hills), the entire terrain feature must be within 240' of the caster. Features over 480' in diameter cannot be affected.

Duration: The illusion lasts until an intelligent creature touches it or until dispelled.
Hallucinatory Terrain.name: Hallucinatory Terrain
Hallucinatory Terrain.spellEffect: Changes or hides terrain in 240' radius (or less)

Hammer, Small.description: Used to drive iron spikes into hard surfaces such as stone or wood. It can also be wielded as a weapon, dealing 1d3 points of damage. This item is necessary for setting up certain equipment like ropes or tents.
Hammer, Small.name: Hammer, Small

Harden*.description:
This spell turns an area of mud into solid rock, permanently. The affected area can be up to 3,000 square feet in surface area and 10' deep. The caster may shape the area within these limits (e.g., 20' x 150', 30' x 100').

Creatures caught within the area must make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being trapped in the hardened mud.
Harden*.name: Harden*

Haste*.description:
This spell increases the movement and attack speed of up to 24 creatures within a 60' diameter area, allowing them to act at double speed for 3 turns.

Effects: Hasted creatures move at twice normal speed and make double the normal number of attacks in melee or with missile weapons. However, magic use is unaffected, so spellcasters can still only cast one spell per round, and magical devices are unaffected.

Reverse Spell: The reverse, *Slow*, either cancels *Haste* or reduces the target’s movement and attack speed by half. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid *Slow*.
Haste*.name: Haste*
Haste*.spellEffect: Up to 24 creatures move double speed

Healing.description: Healing allows the treatment of wounds and diagnosis of illnesses among humans and demihumans. A successful skill roll can restore 1d3 hit points to a wounded character. This skill can only be used once per set of wounds, defined as all hit points lost in a single combat. A natural roll of 20 accidentally inflicts [[/r 1d3 #Healing hit points restored]] damage, and the healer may not attempt to treat those wounds again. Success with a roll of 5 or more indicates the healer can determine if an illness is natural or magically induced.
Healing.name: Healing

Hear Noise.description: The thief has a heightened sense of hearing, allowing them to detect faint noises such as footsteps, whispers, and the movements of hidden creatures.
Hear Noise.name: Hear Noise

Heat Metal.description:
This spell causes one metal object to slowly heat and then cool. It can affect one metal item weighing up to one-half pound (5 cn) per level of the caster. For example, a 12th level caster can heat up to 6 pounds (60 cn), such as a normal sword, while a 20th level caster can heat up to 10 pounds (100 cn), enough to heat a two-handed sword.

The heat does not damage magical items but may severely damage normal weapons or items, especially if they contain both wood and metal. If held, the object causes increasing damage each round: 1 point in the first round, 2 in the second, 4 in the third, and 8 in the fourth. The damage then decreases at the same rate over the remaining rounds. In the fourth round, leather, wood, and other flammable materials in contact with the metal catch fire. Total damage over seven rounds is 22 points.

The holder gets no saving throw, but fire resistance negates all damage. The holder can drop the item at any time, and creatures of low intelligence are 80% likely to do so each round. The spell disrupts concentration, preventing spellcasting for the duration of damage.

Once cast, the spell does not require concentration. Only a dispel magic spell can stop it; normal means, like immersion in water, do not affect it. If cast on an object embedded in a creature (like an arrow or dagger), removing it causes the loss of initiative for that round and inflicts damage for that round as well.
Heat Metal.name: Heat Metal

Hide in Shadows.description: The thief can blend into shadows and become nearly invisible, moving silently as long as they remain still or move cautiously.
Hide in Shadows.name: Hide in Shadows

Hiding Ability (indoors).description: Halflings can hide with a 90% success rate in natural surroundings when staying still. Indoors, they have a 33% chance of hiding successfully in shadows or behind cover.
Hiding Ability (indoors).name: Hiding Ability (indoors)

Hiding Ability (natural).description: Halflings can hide with a 90% success rate in natural surroundings when staying still. Indoors, they have a 33% chance of hiding successfully in shadows or behind cover.
Hiding Ability (natural).name: Hiding Ability (natural)

Hold Animal.description:
This spell paralyzes normal or giant-sized animals within a range of 180'. The spell does not affect creatures with greater than animal intelligence (2) or fantastic creatures.

Effect: Each animal makes a saving throw vs. spells to resist paralysis for the spell’s duration. The druid can affect 1 Hit Die of animals per caster level, ignoring any “pluses” to Hit Dice. For example, a 20th-level druid could hold 10 giant toads (2 + 2 HD each).

This spell can also affect summoned, conjured, or controlled animals.
Hold Animal.name: Hold Animal
Hold Animal.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Hold Monster*.description:
This spell paralyzes [[/r 1d4 #living creatures]] 1-4 living creatures, with effects similar to a *Hold Person* spell, but able to target any living creature (not undead).

Saving Throw: Each creature must make a saving throw vs. spells to resist. If cast on a single target, the creature suffers a -2 penalty to the saving throw. If cast on a group, it affects 1d4 creatures (chosen by the caster and within range) with no saving throw penalty.

Reverse Spell - Free Monster: The reverse of this spell, *Free Monster*, removes the paralysis from up to four creatures affected by *Hold Person* or *Hold Monster*. It has no other effects.
Hold Monster*.name: Hold Monster*
