Hold Monster*.spellDuration: 6 turns + 1 turn per level of the caster

Hold Person*.description:
This spell paralyzes up to four creatures, affecting any human, demihuman, or human-like beings such as bugbears, dryads, gnolls, hobgoblins, kobolds, lizard men, ogres, orcs, nixies, pixies, or sprites. It does not affect undead or creatures larger than ogres. Each target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be paralyzed for nine turns. If the spell is cast at a single target, that creature receives a -2 penalty to their saving throw. If cast at a group, up to four creatures of the spellcaster's choice can be affected, but without any penalty to their saving throws. The paralysis can only be removed by the reversed form of this spell or a dispel magic spell.

The reversed spell, free person, lifts the paralysis from up to four victims affected by the normal form of the spell (including *hold person* cast by a magic-user or an elf). It has no effect on other forms of paralysis, such as that caused by a ghoul.
Hold Person*.name: Hold Person*

Hold Portal.description:
This spell magically holds a door, gate, or similar portal shut for 2-12 turns. A knock spell can open it, or a creature with three or more Hit Dice (or levels) above the caster can break it in one round. If the portal closes within the spell’s duration, it will relock.

Example: A 5th level character can break through a hold portal spell cast by a 2nd level spellcaster.
Hold Portal.name: Hold Portal
Hold Portal.spellEffect: One door, gate, or similar portal

Holy Symbol.description: This is a sign or symbol of a cleric's beliefs. It is often used to physically ward off vampires, and DMs may make holy symbols necessary for a cleric to turn undead.
Holy Symbol.name: Holy Symbol

Holy Water.description: This water is made holy by a high-level cleric and can cause damage to undead creatures. It is typically stored in a breakable vial or gourd and can be thrown to splash the target.
Holy Water.name: Holy Water

Hooded Lantern.description:
A hooded lantern is a portable light source enclosed within a metal casing, designed to control the amount and direction of light it emits. The lantern features a hinged, adjustable hood that can be raised or lowered to focus or block the light as needed. When fully opened, the lantern casts light in a 30-foot radius. When the hood is partially closed, the light is reduced to a narrower beam that casts light 50 feet.

The lantern burns one flask of oil over the course of four hours (24 turns). Its enclosed design helps protect the flame from wind and rain, making it more reliable in outdoor or adverse conditions compared to an open flame.
Hooded Lantern.name: Hooded Lantern

Hunting.description: This skill covers the ability to locate, stalk, and hunt game with weapons like bows, slings, or spears. A successful skill roll grants a +1 to hit against unaware targets in peaceful outdoor settings. This bonus does not apply in combat. The character can automatically supply themselves with food in fertile areas and make skill rolls in less abundant regions. The roll has penalties when trying to supply more than one person, with a -1 penalty per additional person.
Hunting.name: Hunting

Ice Storm.description:
This spell creates a storm of ice in a 20' x 20' x 20' area, or the largest available space within those dimensions, dealing 1d6 cold damage per caster level to all creatures in the area.

Saving Throw: Each creature may make a saving throw vs. spells for half damage. Fire-type creatures (e.g., red dragons, flame salamanders) suffer a -4 penalty to their saving throws, while cold-type creatures (e.g., frost giants, frost salamanders) are unaffected.
Ice Storm.name: Ice Storm

Immunity to Ghoul Paralysis.description: Elves are immune to the paralyzing attacks of ghouls. They are, however, still affected by other forms of paralysis.
Immunity to Ghoul Paralysis.name: Immunity to Ghoul Paralysis

Infravision.description: Elves have infravision, allowing them to see in the dark up to 60 feet. They can perceive creatures and objects based on their temperature difference from the surroundings.
Infravision.name: Infravision

Ink, vial.description: A vial of black ink. Coloured ink costs double. Sufficient for about 50 pages of writing.
Ink, vial.name: Ink, vial

Insect Plague.description:
This spell summons a vast swarm of insects in a 30' radius, obscuring vision and driving off creatures with less than 3 Hit Dice (no saving throw). The caster can direct the swarm to move up to 20' per round within a range of 480' but must remain still and concentrate.

If the caster is disturbed, the insects scatter and the spell ends. This spell can only be cast outdoors and above ground.
Insect Plague.name: Insect Plague

Intimidation.description:
This skill allows the character to coerce or intimidate non-player characters (NPCs) into complying with their demands. Intimidation typically involves an implicit or explicit threat of violence or other consequences if the target does not comply. A successful skill check means the NPC is cowed into submission or action favorable to the character.

The skill is most effective against NPCs with lower levels or morale and is not usable on player characters. It has no effect on characters of 5th level or higher. NPCs subject to successful Intimidation are unlikely to view the character favorably in the future, and the relationship may be permanently damaged.

In situations where physical presence, strength, or combat prowess can be effectively displayed to bolster the threat, the DM may grant a bonus to the roll. However, this skill does not work against targets who are clearly in a superior position (such as a king surrounded by his elite guards).
Intimidation.name: Intimidation

Invisibility.description:
This spell makes any one creature or object invisible. When a creature becomes invisible, all items it carries and wears also become invisible. Any invisible item becomes visible again when it leaves the creature's possession (dropped, set down, etc.). A light source (such as a torch) may be made invisible, but the light given off will remain visible.

If the spellcaster makes an object invisible that is not being carried or worn, it will become visible again when touched by any living creature. An invisible creature remains invisible until they attack or cast any spell.
Invisibility.name: Invisibility

Invisibility 10' Radius.description:
This spell makes the recipient and all other creatures within a 10' radius invisible at the time of casting. Creatures that move more than 10' away from the recipient lose their invisibility and cannot regain it by returning to the area.

The invisibility effect is similar to the standard *Invisibility* spell, where invisible creatures and items carried remain unseen until the creature attacks or casts a spell.

All items carried by affected creatures are also rendered invisible.
Invisibility 10' Radius.name: Invisibility 10' Radius

Iron Spike.description: A large, long iron nail that can have either a flat head or an open circular head. It is used to wedge doors open, provide grips for climbing, or anchor ropes. A hammer is required to drive it into hard surfaces like stone or wood.
Iron Spike.name: Iron Spike

Jacinth.description: Jacinth is a gemstone known for its vibrant orange-red hue. It has a polished, faceted surface that enhances its brilliance and clarity. Often used in jewelry, jacinth is valued for its fiery color and striking appearance.
Jacinth.name: Jacinth

Jade.description: Jade is a gemstone known for its smooth, polished surface and vibrant green color. It often has natural variations in hue and subtle patterns, showcasing its fine texture. Jade is traditionally used in carving and jewelry, valued for its beauty and cultural significance.
Jade.name: Jade

Jasper.description: Jasper is an opaque gemstone featuring earthy tones like red, brown, and yellow. It often has unique natural patterns and a smooth, polished surface, highlighting its rich colors and intricate designs. Jasper is valued for its grounding and protective qualities in various cultures.
Jasper.name: Jasper

Javelin.description: A javelin is a light one-handed throwing spear. Although primarily used as a thrown weapon, it can also be used in melee. Halflings and other small races can use this weapon.
Javelin.name: Javelin

Knock.description:
This spell unlocks any type of lock, including normal and magically locked doors (such as those affected by hold portal or wizard lock). It can also open secret doors, but the door must be located first. The spell does not permanently remove locking magic, which will re-engage once the door is closed again.

Knock can unstick a gate, cause a barred door to open (forcing the bar to fall), and make treasure chests open easily. However, if a door is both locked and barred, only one of the locks will be affected.

Note: If the lock is affected by a spell, the target can make a saving throw vs. spells to resist.
Knock.name: Knock

Know Alignment*.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to determine the alignment (Lawful, Neutral, or Chaotic) of any one creature within 10'. It can also reveal the alignment of an enchanted item or area, if applicable.

The reversed form, confuse alignment, lasts for one turn per level of the spellcaster and can be cast on a creature by touch. No saving throw is allowed. For the duration of the spell, any attempt to discern the recipient's alignment will yield a false result. This false alignment will remain consistent for all subsequent detection attempts during the spell's duration.
Know Alignment*.name: Know Alignment*

Knowledge (choose type).description: The character is an expert in one field of study such as history, theology, or geography. A character can make a living teaching or acting as an expert on the chosen subject. With a successful roll, they can provide detailed commentary or insights on the field of study. The specific type of knowledge must be defined, and multiple skills can be chosen for expertise in different subjects.
Knowledge (choose type).name: Knowledge (choose type)

Labor.description: This skill represents expertise in one type of manual labor such as bricklaying, farming, mining, or stonecutting. Characters can make their living with this skill and interpret information related to their occupation. Specify which type of labor the skill pertains to, such as bricklaying, mining, or stonecutting. A character can select multiple Labor skills, each representing a different proficiency.
Labor.name: Labor

Lance Attack.description: When mounted and using a lance, a fighter can perform a powerful charge attack. The fighter gains double their Strength modifier to the damage roll if the attack is successful. This ability is most effective when charging against opponents.
Lance Attack.name: Lance Attack

Language (choose type).description: Allows the character to speak and read a specific language beyond their normal allocation. Each additional language is chosen separately, such as Elvish, Dwarven, or Thyatian. The character must make a skill check to understand technical or fast-paced speech in these additional languages.
Language (choose type).name: Language (choose type)

Languages.description: Dwarves can speak the languages of Dwarves, Gnomes, Goblins, and Kobolds, in addition to Common and Alignment tongues.
Languages.name: Languages

Lantern.description: An oil lantern illuminates a 30-foot radius and consumes one flask of oil over four hours (24 turns). Most lanterns are designed to be enclosed or equipped with shutters to shield the flame from the wind​​.
Lantern.name: Lantern

Law and Justice (choose culture).description:
This skill provides a character with a detailed knowledge of the laws and judicial systems of a specific culture or country. Characters who wish to be a judge or advocate (lawyer) must select this skill. Each culture or nation has its own codes, so characters who wish to be conversant in different nations' legal systems must choose this skill separately for each set of laws they wish to study.

A successful skill check can help the character recall specific laws and customs, advise others in legal matters, and argue effectively in courts or other formal settings.
Law and Justice (choose culture).name: Law and Justice (choose culture)

Leadership.description: The Leadership skill represents a character's ability to inspire, command, and direct others. It is used to coordinate group efforts, boost morale, and make strategic decisions in both peaceful and combat situations. Characters with high Leadership can motivate followers, maintain order, and effectively communicate plans to allies.
Leadership.name: Leadership

Leather Armor.description: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates and strips. The leather is often boiled in wax to harden it. Leather armor gives an armor class of 7, and because it is made from natural materials it can be worn by druids. It is also light and quiet enough to be worn by thieves.
Leather Armor.name: Leather Armor

Leather Armor+1.description: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates and strips. The leather is often boiled in wax to harden it. Non-magical leather armor gives an armor class of 7, and because it is made from natural materials it can be worn by druids. It is also light and quiet enough to be worn by thieves.
Leather Armor+1.name: Leather Armor+1

Levitate.description:
This spell allows the caster to move vertically, up or down, without support. The caster cannot move side to side without pushing against something. Vertical movement is at a rate of 20' per round.

The spell can only be cast on the caster, who can carry up to 2,000 cn (200 lbs) while levitating. The caster can carry another man-sized creature if it isn’t wearing metal armor or heavily burdened. No saving throw is allowed for the levitated target.

Duration: 6 turns plus 1 turn per level.
Levitate.name: Levitate

Light*.description:
This spell creates a large ball of light with a 30' diameter, similar to bright torchlight. If cast on an object, the light moves with it. If cast at a creature’s eyes, the target must save vs. spells or be blinded until the spell ends. If the saving throw succeeds, the light appears behind the target.

The reverse, darkness, creates a 30' diameter circle of darkness that blocks all sight except infravision. Darkness can counter light and vice-versa. If cast at a creature’s eyes, the target must save vs. spells or be blinded until the effect ends.
Light*.name: Light*

Lightning Bolt.description:
This spell creates a bolt of lightning that begins up to 180' away from the caster and extends 60' further in a straight line. All creatures within the area of effect take 1d6 points of lightning damage per caster level.

Damage: For example, a 6th-level elf would cast a lightning bolt dealing 6d6 points of damage. Each creature in the path of the bolt may make a saving throw vs. spells for half damage.

Special Effect: If the bolt strikes a solid surface, it bounces back toward the caster until it reaches its full length of 60'.
Lightning Bolt.name: Lightning Bolt

Lip Reading.description: Allows the character to "overhear" a conversation by watching the target's lips. The character must be able to see the target and understand the language being spoken. Success means the character understands the conversation. The distance and available light affect the difficulty of the skill check.
Lip Reading.name: Lip Reading

Listen Door.description:
Listening for noises is a skill any character can attempt, commonly used at doors or in other quiet environments. To attempt this, the area must be silent, and all party members must remain still to avoid interfering with the attempt. The Dungeon Master rolls or the player rolls blind, whether or not a sound exists, to maintain player uncertainty. A successful roll allows the character to hear any detectable noises if conditions permit.
Demi-humans, such as dwarves, elves, and halflings, get a bonus of 1 for their listen roll. Thieves also gain increased effectiveness at this task as they progress in levels​​.
Listen Door.name: Listen Door

Locate.description:
This spell allows the druid to sense the direction of one known normal or giant-sized animal or plant within 120 feet. The caster must name the exact type of animal or plant, but does not need to see the specific one to locate it. This spell cannot locate fantastic creatures, plant monsters, or any intelligent creatures or plants.

The animal or plant gets no saving throw. (This spell is most often used to find special rare plants.)
Locate.name: Locate

Locate Object.description: This spell allows the caster to sense the direction of a known object within range, but not its distance. It can detect a common object with a partial description, such as "stairs leading up," but will only indicate the direction of the nearest such object. To find a specific object, the caster must know exactly what the object looks like (size, shape, color, etc.). The spell will not locate a creature.
Locate Object.name: Locate Object

Mace +1.description: A mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.
Mace +1.name: Mace +1

Mace +2.description: A mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.
Mace +2.name: Mace +2

Magic Duel.description: Experienced Magic-Users can engage in magical duels, using their spells and abilities to counter or disrupt another caster’s magic. This is often used to resolve conflicts between rival spellcasters.
Magic Duel.name: Magic Duel

Magic Jar.description:
This spell transfers the caster's life force into an inanimate object within 30' (referred to as a "magic jar" regardless of its form). The caster’s body falls into a trance. From the magic jar, the caster can attempt to possess a creature within 120' of the jar.

Possession Attempt: The target must make a saving throw vs. spells. If successful, the caster cannot attempt to possess that creature again for one turn. If failed, the caster takes over the creature’s body, and the creature’s life force is transferred to the magic jar.

Actions in Possessed Body: The caster can perform normal actions, but no special abilities (similar to *Polymorph Self*). A *Dispel Evil* spell forces the caster's life force back into the magic jar.

Destruction Effects: If the magic jar is destroyed while the caster's life force is within, the caster dies. If the jar is destroyed while the caster possesses a body, the caster is stranded in that body, and the original owner's life force is destroyed. If the caster’s original body is destroyed, they are stranded in the magic jar until a new body is taken.

Taking over another body is considered a Chaotic act.
Magic Jar.name: Magic Jar

Magic Missile.description:
This spell creates a glowing arrow that inflicts [[/r 1d6+1 #Magic missile damage]] (2-7) points of damage to any visible target specified by the caster. The arrow always hits and no saving throw is allowed. After the spell is cast, the arrow appears next to the caster and hovers there until shot.

For every 5 levels of experience, two additional missiles are created by the same spell. The caster can direct these missiles at one or multiple targets.
Magic Missile.name: Magic Missile

Magic-User.description:
A magic-user is a human character dedicated to the study of arcane knowledge and the casting of spells. They are among the most versatile and powerful classes but are physically fragile and limited in combat abilities. Their focus on magic allows them to wield extraordinary power as they gain experience.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Intelligence, granting an experience bonus for high scores (5% for 13–15, 10% for 16–18).
  • Combat Skills: Magic-users cannot wear armor or use shields and are restricted to using daggers. At the DM's discretion, other light weapons such as staves or slings may be permitted.
  • Hit Dice: They use a d4 for hit points per level up to 9th level. Beyond that, they gain a fixed 1 hit point per level without Constitution bonuses.
  • Spellcasting: Magic-users learn and prepare spells from a spellbook. Their magic includes a wide range of effects, such as attack spells (e.g., Fireball), utility spells (e.g., Knock), and defensive spells (e.g., Shield).

Advancement:

  • At 9th level (Name level), a magic-user becomes a "Wizard" (male) or "Maga" (female). Wizards can create magic items, such as scrolls or potions.
  • Magic-users may construct a tower as a personal stronghold. Once completed, the tower attracts 1d6 apprentices (1st–3rd level magic-users), who serve the wizard as students and assistants.
  • If a dungeon is built beneath or near the tower and left unguarded, it may attract monsters. Some wizards encourage this to create a ready source of material for research and training.

Stronghold Options:

  • Independent Wizards: Magic-users building their own towers typically do so without seeking approval from local rulers. However, gaining the ruler's favor might result in gifts or an official title to the land.
  • Magists: Magic-users can serve as court wizards, known as Magists, advising rulers on magical matters in exchange for room, board, and a stipend (usually 3,000 gp per month or more). This arrangement allows continued magical research, often funded by the ruler.

Magic-users begin their careers as fragile and vulnerable adventurers but grow into formidable spellcasters capable of altering the course of campaigns with their arcane abilities. Their strongholds often serve as hubs of magical research and influence.
Magic-User.name: Magic-User

Magic-User Spells.description: Elves can cast Magic-User spells, though they receive fewer and lower-level spells compared to a Magic-User of the same level.
Magic-User Spells.name: Magic-User Spells

Magical Engineering.description: Grants the ability to recognize the basic principles behind unfamiliar magical devices. This does not include training in the design or fabrication of magical artifacts but does allow identification of common magical items with a successful skill check. It doesn't allow a character to recognize uncommon magical items or to distinguish trapped or cursed items from those that are safe.
Magical Engineering.name: Magical Engineering

Mapping / Cartography.description: A character with this skill can understand and create maps, even if they cannot read and write. No roll is needed to comprehend simple maps, but a skill roll is necessary for interpreting or drafting complex layouts. Mapping skill can be used to map an area from memory or to draw accurate maps of places visited. This skill is useful for explorers, adventurers, and merchants.
Mapping / Cartography.name: Mapping / Cartography

Massmorph.description:
This spell causes up to 100 human- or man-sized creatures within a 240' diameter to appear as trees, such as in an orchard or dense forest. The type of tree or plant life should be appropriate to the terrain and environment (for instance, it typically would not work in a desert without large cacti).

Target Types: Only willing creatures are affected. Larger creatures, like horses, can be included, counting as two or three men-sized creatures each.

Effect: The illusion hides recipients from others moving through the affected area. A creature’s normal appearance returns if it moves out of the area, but movement within the area does not break the illusion. The spell lasts until dispelled or dismissed by the caster.
Massmorph.name: Massmorph
Massmorph.spellEffect: Causes illusion of trees within 240' range

Military Tactics.description: This skill allows a character to analyze the movement of enemy forces and effectively position their own troops. The player describes their tactical plan, and the DM rolls a Military Tactics skill check. If successful, the DM confirms the plan is viable and offers additional strategic insights. A failed roll means the character misinterprets the enemy's intentions or chooses an ineffective strategy.
Military Tactics.name: Military Tactics

Mimicry.description: The character can convincingly imitate animal sounds and foreign accents. This is particularly useful in wilderness settings, such as when communicating with allies using animal calls or deceiving enemies by imitating their language or speech patterns. A successful skill check ensures the mimicry is indistinguishable from the real sound or accent.
Mimicry.name: Mimicry

Mirror.description: This hand-sized steel mirror is used to look around corners or defend against gaze attacks. When used to observe a foe, the user suffers a -2 penalty to attack rolls and cannot use a shield as they are holding the mirror. The area must be lit for it to be effective.
Mirror.name: Mirror

Mirror Image.description:
This spell creates [[/r 1d4 #Number of Images]] illusory duplicates of the spellcaster that move and act like them. The images stay within 3' of the caster and imitate their movements and speech without requiring concentration.

The images are not real and cannot take any actions. Any successful attack that would hit the spellcaster instead destroys one of the images, regardless of damage. This continues until all images are gone. Area attacks, such as a fireball, destroy all images at once and also affect the spellcaster.
Mirror Image.name: Mirror Image

Mountaineering.description: This skill covers the techniques and physical ability required for climbing steep and hazardous terrains, such as mountains and cliffs. Characters with Mountaineering can navigate difficult slopes, secure safe paths, and assist others in ascent or descent. The skill can also be used to avoid dangers like rockslides or falling.
Mountaineering.name: Mountaineering

Move Silently.description: The thief can move without making any noise, avoiding detection when trying to sneak past others.
Move Silently.name: Move Silently

Multiple Attacks.description:
This maneuver is a Fighter Combat Option available to human fighters starting at level 12, and to demihumans at different experience levels (refer to their experience tables). In melee combat, if the fighter can hit an opponent with a roll of 2 or higher (after applying all modifiers), they gain two attacks per round against that target. At level 24, this increases to three attacks per round, and at level 36, it becomes four attacks per round.

Each attack in this series can be a different type, including a throw, a standard attack, a lance attack, or a disarm. The fighter can combine these maneuvers in any sequence; for example, a character with three attacks per round could perform an attack, a disarm, and another attack, or throw three knives in succession. This maneuver is most effective under optimal conditions, and the character can replace any attack with movement or another action if desired.
Multiple Attacks.name: Multiple Attacks

Muscle.description:
The Muscle skill represents a character's training in heavy lifting and strenuous physical tasks, such as opening stuck doors, breaking objects, or moving large weights. Characters with this skill can direct groups of laborers to optimize their efforts when moving heavy loads or using simple machinery like pulleys and levers.

With a successful skill check, the character gains a +2 bonus on Strength checks for tasks involving raw physical power, such as forcing open a door or bending bars. This skill is invaluable for characters who frequently engage in physically demanding situations.

The skill also allows the character to apply basic principles of physics to their advantage, using leverage and technique to multiply their effective strength. Many characters who are laborers, warriors, or athletes commonly possess this skill.
Muscle.name: Muscle

Music (choose type).description: The Music skill represents a character's proficiency with a specific type of musical instrument, such as a lute, harp, or drum. The chosen instrument type must be specified when the skill is selected. Characters with this skill can perform melodies that entertain, inspire, or soothe. A successful Music check can influence the mood of an audience, enhance the effects of magical performances, or distract opponents.
Music (choose type).name: Music (choose type)

Mystic Natural Armor.description:
• Mystic Special Abilities Table

*The mystic receives the Fighter Combat Options (excluding multiple attacks); see the description of them under "Combat Maneuvers" in Chapter 8. The mystic can use these Combat Options with weapons or in unarmed fighting.
Mystic Natural Armor.name: Mystic Natural Armor

Mysticism.description:
This skill allows a character to instinctively know the proper actions to take in order to please the Immortals in general. A successful skill check can indicate the appropriate behavior or ritual to use when encountering sacred objects, places, or situations related to the Immortals.

For example, a successful check might reveal that the party should leave an offering at a shrine or avoid disturbing a holy site. This skill also allows a character to recognize symbols and artifacts of the Immortals, as well as to interpret omens or signs given by them.
Mysticism.name: Mysticism

Name-Level Benefits.description: At Name level (9th), an elf can build a stronghold deep in the forest. Friendly animals within 5 miles of the stronghold will aid the elf by providing warnings, delivering messages, and helping in other ways.
Name-Level Benefits.name: Name-Level Benefits

Nature Lore.description: This skill provides knowledge of plant and animal life in a specific terrain (e.g., desert, forest, jungle). The character can identify edible and poisonous plants, spot signs of unnatural danger, and know when something is out of place in the natural environment. When used in the character's home terrain, they receive a -2 bonus to their skill check; in unfamiliar but similar terrain, no bonus or penalty applies; in very different terrain, a penalty of up to +4 may be imposed.
Nature Lore.name: Nature Lore

Navigation.description: By taking directions from the position of the sun and the stars (or other atmospheric phenomena appropriate in your campaign), the character can always know roughly where they are. Successful skill rolls, with positive or negative modifiers for the character's distance from their home territory and familiarity with their surroundings, will tell the character more precisely where they are. This skill can prevent parties from getting lost and may help them reorient when disoriented in unknown regions. The DM may require a check every day to keep the party on course.
Navigation.name: Navigation

Net (6'x6').description:
A net is an open weave of rope or cord that serves as a versatile tool and weapon. Small nets, measuring up to 10' x 10', are commonly used in hunting and adventuring. They can function as either hand-to-hand or thrown weapons. The encumbrance of a net depends on its size. Widely available in most campaign settings, nets are inexpensive but easily damaged. They are one of humanity’s earliest tools, used since prehistoric times, and are popular among humanoid monsters for hunting and defense.

Nets are only effective against creatures with a solid form. They do not work on wraiths, spectres, ethereal beings, or creatures made of water, like water elementals. While nets cause no physical damage, they can entangle, slow, or delay a target. To ensnare a target, the wielder must succeed on a normal attack roll. If successful, the target must then make a saving throw vs. death ray, potentially with bonuses from the Weapon Special Effects Table. A successful save negates the effect, and the net falls away harmlessly. Failure results in one of several effects depending on the target's size or experience.

An entangled victim may attempt a saving throw each round during the hand-to-hand combat phase to free themselves. Success indicates the net has been removed. If the target has a dagger (but not a longer or non-bladed weapon) in hand when ensnared, they gain a +4 bonus to their saving throw. If successful, the dagger cuts through and destroys the net.

Net and Target Size:

Nets are sized to correspond with the dimensions of their intended targets. Targets larger than the net gain bonuses to their saving throw based on the difference in size. For each size category larger, the target receives a +4 bonus to the save. A natural roll of 1 is always a failure unless the total bonus is +20 or more. The Nets Table provides the appropriate net size for various victim sizes.

Nets Table:

Victim's SizeApproximate HeightNet Size
Very smallUp to 1'2' x 2'
Small1+ to 3'4' x 4'
Medium3+ to 6'6' x 6'
Large6+ to 10'9' x 9'
Very large10+ to 15'12' x 12'
Huge15+ to 20'16' x 16'
Mammoth20+ to 30'25' x 25'

Nets measuring 6' x 6' or smaller can be wielded with one hand. Larger nets require two hands and are subject to penalties associated with two-handed weapons. The wielder cannot use a shield, always loses individual initiative against those not using two-handed weapons, and halflings or small humanoids (like goblins) cannot use nets larger than 6' x 6'.

Magical Nets:

Magical nets are rare and impervious to all but fire or acid. Daggers and other weapons cannot cut through them, and an ensnared victim can only remove the net, not destroy it.

Effects of Ensnarement:

When ensnared, a victim suffers one of the following effects, as determined by the Weapon Special Effects Table:

  • Entangle: The victim cannot move, attack, or cast spells until a successful saving throw.
  • Slow: The victim’s movement and attacks are halved, and they cannot cast spells.
  • Delay: The victim automatically loses initiative in the next round.

Durability and Repair:

A net is easily damaged by edged weapons, claws, or bites. If damaged, it becomes useless unless repaired. Repairing a net requires 1d3 turns of uninterrupted work with rope or cord.

A well-maintained net remains a practical and effective tool for adventurers, offering non-lethal means of control and strategy in combat.
Net (6'x6').name: Net (6'x6')

Neutralize Poison*.description: This spell renders any poison harmless in a creature, container, or on an object. It can revive a creature poisoned within the last 10 rounds but does not heal any other damage.
Neutralize Poison*.name: Neutralize Poison*

Obscure.description:
This spell causes a misty vapor to rise from the ground, forming a large cloud. The cloud's height is 1 foot per caster level, and its diameter is 10 feet per level. For example, a 20th-level caster could create a cloud 20 feet high and 200 feet in diameter.

The cloud blocks vision, though the caster and creatures that can see invisible objects can see dimly through it. Other creatures in the cloud are effectively blind, delayed, and confused by the effect.
Obscure.name: Obscure
Obscure.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Oil, flask.description: Oil is burned in a lantern for light. A flask of oil may also be thrown as a missile weapon or poured out and ignited to delay pursuit.
Oil, flask.name: Oil, flask

Onyx.description: Onyx is a gemstone characterized by its deep black color, often with subtle white banding or lines. It has a smooth, polished surface with a glossy appearance, making it popular in jewelry and decorative pieces for its sleek and elegant look.
Onyx.name: Onyx

Opal.description: Opal is a gemstone known for its captivating play of colors, displaying flashes of blue, green, red, and yellow on a smooth, polished surface. Its iridescence and unique patterns make it highly valued in jewelry, adding a vibrant and mesmerizing effect to any piece.
Opal.name: Opal

Open Door.description:
The Open Doors roll represents a character's ability to force open stuck doors. At the DM's discretion, it may also be used to determine the character's capability to perform other feats of strength, such as moving obstacles. Characters with high Strength apply their Strength adjustment to the roll.
Each character may attempt this action once per round. However, if the initial attempt fails, any monsters on the other side of the door will not be surprised, as they will have heard the noise.
Open Door.name: Open Door

Open Locks.description: The character can attempt to pick a lock. Success is based on a percentage determined by their level.
Open Locks.name: Open Locks

Paladin.description:
A Lawful traveling fighter can achieve the title of paladin if they meet specific requirements. Fighters who do not meet these conditions may instead become knights (described separately).

  1. Fealty to a Clerical Order: To become a paladin, the fighter must swear an oath of service to a Lawful clerical order. Only fighters of Name level or higher are eligible. Once accepted, the paladin is bound to serve the order and may be summoned by its leaders at any time to perform tasks that align with the powers of Good.

  2. Detect Evil: A paladin can detect evil, as per the cleric spell, once per round by concentrating. This ability has a range of 120 feet but cannot be used in the same round as an attack.

  3. Cleric Spells: A paladin with a Wisdom score of 13 or higher can cast cleric spells as if they were a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 17th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 5th-level cleric. Fighters with Wisdom scores of 12 or less can still become paladins but cannot cast spells. Paladins are trained in meditation and spellcasting by the clerics of their order, who provide this service without accepting compensation.

  4. Turn Undead: Paladins can turn undead with the same ability as a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the paladin turns undead as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 16th or 17th level, the paladin turns undead as a 5th-level cleric.

  5. Hireling Limit: The paladin can be accompanied by a number of hirelings equal to or less than their effective clerical level. For example, a paladin with the abilities of a 5th-level cleric may travel with up to five hirelings.

  6. Assisting Others: A paladin must provide aid to anyone who requests it, except in the following cases:

    • The paladin is not obligated to assist evil individuals or support evil goals.
    • If engaged in a mission for a higher authority (such as a quest or serving a noble), the paladin may offer limited help, such as advice or temporary shelter, and must explain their inability to provide further assistance. Aid is limited to services and does not include monetary or material donations.

Paladin Turn Undead Table
