Legend:

  • 7, 9, 11: Roll 2d6 and meet or exceed this number to turn undead.
  • T: Automatically turn undead.
  • D: Automatically destroy undead.
  • D+: Automatically destroy [[/r 3d6 #Hit Dice]] Hit Dice of undead.
Paladin.name: Paladin

Parry.description: This is a Fighter Combat Option maneuver accessible to fighters and mystics starting at 9th level, and to demihumans at other specific experience levels (refer to their experience tables). When using this maneuver, the fighter does not make an attack roll. Instead, they focus on blocking incoming attacks for the entire combat round, imposing a -4 penalty on all melee and thrown weapon attacks made against them (but not missile weapon attacks).
Parry.name: Parry

Pass Plant.description:
This spell allows the druid to teleport between two trees of the same type. The trees must be large enough to enclose the druid. Upon casting, the druid can step into one tree and immediately step out of another within range.

Teleportation Range by Tree Type:

Tree TypeRange
Oak600 yards
Ash, Elm, Linden, Yew360 yards
Evergreen trees300 yards
Other trees240 yards
Pass Plant.name: Pass Plant

Passwall.description:
This spell creates a hole 5' in diameter and 10' deep in solid rock or stone only. The hole may be oriented horizontally or vertically.

End of Duration: When the spell ends, the stone reappears. Any creature still in the hole at that time must make a saving throw vs. turn to stone. On a success, the creature is ejected from the nearest end of the tunnel; on a failure, the creature is trapped and killed.
Passwall.name: Passwall

Pearl.description: Pearl is a gemstone with a smooth, round surface and a lustrous, iridescent sheen. It reflects soft colors like white, pink, and silver, highlighting its elegant and natural beauty. Pearls are highly valued in jewelry for their classic and radiant appearance.
Pearl.name: Pearl

Persuasion.description: The Persuasion skill allows a character to influence others through convincing arguments, charm, or logical reasoning. It is used to sway opinions, negotiate peace, or convince someone to take a particular course of action. Successful Persuasion can resolve conflicts, gain allies, or secure valuable information.
Persuasion.name: Persuasion

Phantasmal Force.description:
This spell creates an illusion that affects everything within the specified area. The illusion can be of anything the caster has seen before. If the caster creates something they have not seen, targets receive a bonus to their saving throws to disbelieve the illusion.

Non-attacking illusions disappear when touched. If the illusion mimics an attack (like a magic missile or a collapsing wall), the target may save vs. spells to negate its effects. The illusionary creature has AC 9 and disappears when struck.

The phantasmal force persists as long as the caster maintains concentration. If the caster moves, is damaged, or fails a saving throw, concentration is lost and the illusion vanishes. The spell causes no real damage. Those "killed" by it merely fall unconscious for [[/r 1d4 #turns]] turns, and any effects like "turning to stone" result in temporary paralysis.
Phantasmal Force.name: Phantasmal Force

Pick Pockets.description: The character can attempt to pick pockets or take small items from people without being noticed.
Pick Pockets.name: Pick Pockets

Piloting (choose type).description: This skill represents the ability to control and maneuver a specific type of vehicle, such as a ship, airship, or magical conveyance. The chosen type must be specified when the skill is selected. Piloting involves steering, navigating obstacles, and managing the vehicle in various conditions, such as weather or combat situations.
Piloting (choose type).name: Piloting (choose type)

Planar Geography.description: This skill provides the character with a general knowledge of the Prime, inner, outer, Astral, and Ethereal Planes. The skill includes knowledge of techniques for traveling between these planes, as well as common inhabitants and natural phenomena found within these planes. Characters skilled in Planar Geography are familiar with the traits of these planes, such as time, gravity, and elemental influences.
Planar Geography.name: Planar Geography

Plant Door.description:
This spell allows the druid to pass freely through any plant growth or barrier, no matter how dense. Trees, vines, and other plants will bend or magically open to create a passage for the druid, who can carry equipment while moving through but cannot bring other creatures with them.

The druid may also hide inside a large tree after casting this spell, though they cannot see what is happening outside the tree while within.
Plant Door.name: Plant Door
Plant Door.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Plate Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of large metal plates—the largest being the breastplate—linked together with chain mail. Plate mail gives a character an armor class of 3. It is the best armor that can be bought second hand or looted, since suit armor must be custom made.
Plate Mail.name: Plate Mail

Polearm.description: This weapon covers all other polearm varieties that are not individually listed in the weapons list. Some of these weapons include the bardiche, bill, glaive, partizan, ranseur, spetum and voulge. See rules for specials.
Polearm.name: Polearm

Poleaxe.description: A poleaxe consists of an axe blade (usually single sided, but occasionally double sided) with a 6’ to 8' long shaft. It is wielded in both hands like a large two-handed axe.
Poleaxe.name: Poleaxe

Polymorph Other.description:
This spell transforms the target into another living creature, provided the new form has no more than twice as many Hit Dice as the original. The spell fails if this condition is not met.

Effects of Transformation: The target's hit points remain unchanged, but they gain all special abilities, tendencies, and behaviors of the new form. For example, a hobgoblin transformed into a mule would think and act as a mule.

This spell cannot create an exact duplicate of a specific individual but only changes the creature’s type or race. For instance, transforming into a “human” does not grant levels or special skills beyond a basic human form.

Saving Throw: The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to avoid transformation. The spell lasts until dispelled or the creature dies.
Polymorph Other.name: Polymorph Other

Polymorph Self.description:
This spell allows the caster to take on the physical form of another living creature, provided the new form’s Hit Dice are equal to or less than the caster's. If this condition is not met, the spell fails.

Physical Abilities: The caster retains their own AC, hit points, attack rolls, and saving throws, and does not gain special abilities (like a ghoul's paralysis) or immunities of the new form. However, they gain the physical capabilities of the form. For example, a caster polymorphed into a frost giant would gain giant strength and the ability to throw boulders, but not cold immunity. A dragon form would allow flight but not breath attacks or spellcasting.

Limitations: The caster cannot cast spells while polymorphed. The spell lasts for 6 turns + 1 turn per caster level, until dispelled, or until the caster is killed. This spell cannot be used to assume the form of a specific individual.
Polymorph Self.name: Polymorph Self
Polymorph Self.spellDuration: 6 turns + 1 turn per level of the caster

Potion of Agility.description: This potion increases the drinker's Dexterity score to 18 for 7-12 turns [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Agility duration]]. All applicable Dexterity bonuses, such as improved Armor Class and ranged attack bonuses, are applied during this time. The potion takes effect immediately upon consumption.
Potion of Agility.name: Potion of Agility

Potion of Animal Control.description: Upon consuming this potion, the user can control up to [[/r 3d6 #Potion of Animal Control Hit Dice worth of animals]] Hit Dice worth of animals (normal or giant, but not fantastic or magical) for the potion’s duration. Affected animals will be afraid and leave the area when the control ends. The user must see the animals to control them, and cannot force them to harm themselves. The controlled creatures can make a saving throw vs. spells to resist. The potion's effect lasts for [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Animal Control duration]] 7-12 turns.
Potion of Animal Control.name: Potion of Animal Control

Potion of Antidote.description:
This potion grants immunity to certain poisons and provides a +2 bonus to saving throws against poison. The weakest version protects against poisons from creatures with 3 Hit Dice or less, while stronger antidotes counter poisons from more powerful creatures. Poisons avoided during the potion's duration have no effect after it ends.

Roll [[/br 1d10]] to determine which poisons it counters.

1-4: Protects against poisons from creatures of 3 Hit Dice or less.
5-7: Protects against poisons from creatures of 7 Hit Dice or less.
8-9: Protects against poisons from creatures of 15 Hit Dice or less.
10: Protects against all types of poison.
The effect lasts for one hour after consumption.
Potion of Antidote.name: Potion of Antidote

Potion of Blending.description: This potion allows the drinker to blend into their surroundings, making them nearly impossible to detect visually. Unlike a potion of invisibility, normal actions do not dispel the effect. The potion lasts for 7-12 turns [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Blending duration]], with the exact duration known only to the DM.
Potion of Blending.name: Potion of Blending

Potion of Bug Repellent.description: This potion repels all types of bugs, including arachnids (spiders, ticks, scorpions), insects (ants, beetles, flies), and chilopods (centipedes, millipedes). Normal bugs cannot touch the user after drinking the potion. Giant-sized bugs will ignore the user unless they succeed on a saving throw vs. spells. If the save succeeds, the potion has no effect on the giant bug. The potion also grants a +4 bonus to any saving throws against magically summoned or controlled bugs. The potion lasts for [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Bug Repellent duration]] turns.
Potion of Bug Repellent.name: Potion of Bug Repellent

Potion of Healing.description: This potion restores 2-7 hit points [[/r 1d6+1 #Potion of Healing hit points restored.]] or cures paralysis for a single creature. Its effects take place immediately upon consumption.
Potion of Healing.name: Potion of Healing

Potion of Invisibility.description: This potion grants the effects of the invisibility spell. It makes the drinker and their carried items invisible. Any item will become visible again once it leaves the drinker’s possession. The potion may be consumed in up to six sips, each providing invisibility for one turn.
Potion of Invisibility.name: Potion of Invisibility

Potion of Invulnerability.description: This potion grants a +2 bonus to the user's Armor Class and saving throws for the duration of the effect. However, if consumed more than once in a week, it only causes sickness and has no additional effect. The duration is [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Invulnerability duration]] turns.
Potion of Invulnerability.name: Potion of Invulnerability

Potion of Neutralize Poison.description: This potion contains a shimmering green liquid that neutralizes any poison affecting the drinker. It is effective against poisons that have been ingested, inhaled, or injected, but must be consumed within one hour of exposure to work. The drinker is immediately cured of all poison effects upon consumption.
Potion of Neutralize Poison.name: Potion of Neutralize Poison

Pouch, Belt.description: A small pouch made of leather or cloth, typically worn on a belt. It can hold up to 50 coins and is used to carry small valuables or other small items.
Pouch, Belt.name: Pouch, Belt

Predict Weather.description: This spell enables the druid to learn the accurate weather forecast for the next 12 hours within an area of 1 mile in diameter per level of the caster. For example, a 20th-level druid would know the weather within a 20-mile diameter (10-mile radius). This spell does not allow the caster to control the weather, merely to predict it.
Predict Weather.name: Predict Weather

Produce Fire.description:
This spell creates a small flame in the caster's hand. The flame sheds light like a torch and does not harm the caster. It can ignite combustible materials like lanterns, torches, or oil without damaging the magical flame itself.

The caster can make the flame disappear and reappear at will, once per round. The flame can be thrown or dropped up to 30 feet away, but it disappears one round after leaving the caster's hand. Any fire it ignites continues burning.
Produce Fire.name: Produce Fire

Profession (choose type).description: The character is accomplished at one type of non-labor profession, such as politics, cooking, estate management, horse grooming, or scribing. With a successful skill roll, the character can earn a living through this profession and provide expert commentary on related subjects. The player must specify the exact profession the character is skilled in, and a character may have multiple Profession skills to represent expertise in different fields.
Profession (choose type).name: Profession (choose type)

Protection from Evil.description:
This spell creates and invisible magical barrier all around the caster's body (less than an inch away). Here’s the revised text with all references to "cleric" changed to "caster":

While the spell is in effect, characters and monsters attacking the caster suffer a -1 penalty to their attack rolls, and the caster gains a +1 bonus to all saving throws.

Additionally, enchanted creatures are unable to touch the caster! (An enchanted creature is one that normal weapons cannot affect, only magical weapons can hit. A creature that can only be hit by a silver weapon—like a werewolf—is not considered enchanted. Any creature that is magically summoned or controlled, such as a charmed character, is also considered enchanted.) This barrier completely protects the caster from all melee or hand-to-hand attacks from such creatures; however, it does not prevent attacks from missile weapons. Enchanted creatures using missile weapons still suffer the -1 penalty to attack rolls but can still hit the caster.

This spell does not affect a magic missile spell used by magic-users.

If the caster attacks an enchanted creature during the spell's duration, the spell’s effect changes slightly. Enchanted creatures are then able to touch the caster, but still suffer the attack roll penalty; the penalty and the caster's saving throw adjustments remain until the spell's duration ends.
Protection from Evil.name: Protection from Evil

Protection from Evil 10' Radius.description:
This spell creates an invisible barrier around the caster, extending 10' in all directions. It grants each creature within the barrier a +1 bonus to all saving throws, while attacks against those inside suffer a -1 penalty on attack rolls.

Effect: Enchanted creatures (such as magically summoned or controlled beings) cannot engage in melee with anyone inside the barrier. However, if a protected creature attacks an enchanted one, the barrier no longer prevents melee attacks, though saving throw bonuses and attack roll penalties remain active.

Missile and magical attacks from outside the barrier still suffer the -1 attack penalty but are otherwise unaffected.
Protection from Evil 10' Radius.name: Protection from Evil 10' Radius

Protection from Lightning.description:
This spell grants the recipient immunity to a specified amount of electrical damage. The protection amount depends on the druid's experience level: for each level, one die (1d6) of lightning damage is negated. The protected amount is subtracted from the dice of damage that would otherwise be dealt.

Example: A 20th-level druid protected by this spell negates up to 20d6 lightning damage. This would allow the druid to absorb two full *Call Lightning* attacks (8d6 each), plus half of a third attack (8 + 8 + 4 = 20). Any damage beyond this would be taken as normal, and the recipient still makes any applicable saving throws.
Protection from Lightning.name: Protection from Lightning
Protection from Lightning.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Protection from Normal Missiles.description:
This spell grants the recipient complete protection from all small, nonmagical missiles, such as arrows, quarrels, and thrown spears. All such missile attacks automatically miss the target.

Limitations: Large missiles (like catapult stones) and magical missiles (like magic arrows) are unaffected by this spell and can still hit the recipient.

The spell can be cast on any one creature within a range of 30'.
Protection from Normal Missiles.name: Protection from Normal Missiles

Protection from Poison.description:
This spell grants the recipient complete immunity to all poisons for the spell’s duration, including poison from gas traps and *Cloudkill* spells. This protection also extends to any items carried by the recipient, protecting them against poison effects (e.g., a spirit’s poisonous aura).

Bonus to Saving Throws: The recipient also gains a +4 bonus on saving throws against poisonous breath weapons, such as a green dragon’s breath. This bonus does not apply to non-poisonous breath effects, like a gorgon’s petrifying breath.
Protection from Poison.name: Protection from Poison
Protection from Poison.spellDuration: One turn per level of the caster
Protection from Poison.spellEffect: Gives one creature immunity to all poison

Purify Food and Water.description: This spell makes spoiled or poisoned food and water safe for consumption. It can purify one ration of preserved food (either iron or standard rations), six waterskins of water, or enough regular food to feed twelve people. If cast on mud, the spell causes the dirt to settle, leaving behind a pool of pure, clear water. The spell does not affect any living creatures.
Purify Food and Water.name: Purify Food and Water

Quarrels.description: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.
Quarrels.name: Quarrels

Quarrels (silver).description: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.
Quarrels (silver).name: Quarrels (silver)

Quartz.description: Quartz is a clear, transparent gemstone with a crystalline structure. It often appears glass-like, reflecting light with a sparkling brilliance. Its purity and clarity make it a popular choice for jewelry and decorative pieces. There are several different types and colors of quartz.
Quartz.name: Quartz

Quest*.description:
This spell compels the target to undertake a specific task or quest as commanded by the caster. The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to resist; if successful, the spell has no effect.

Typical Tasks: The task might include slaying a particular monster, rescuing a prisoner, retrieving a magical item, or embarking on a pilgrimage. If the task is impossible or suicidal, the spell fails automatically.

Duration: The spell remains in effect until the specified task is completed. This spell compels the target to fulfill the task but does not compel them to do so willingly. Once completed, the target may hold a grudge against the caster, potentially seeking revenge depending on the circumstances of the quest.

Curse: A target who refuses to undertake the quest is cursed until they resume the task. The nature of this curse is determined by the GM and may be twice the usual strength of a standard curse.
Quest*.name: Quest*
Quest*.spellEffect: Compels one creature to perform a task

Quick Draw.description: The Quick Draw skill allows a character to swiftly draw and ready a weapon or item, such as a sword or potion, even in stressful situations like combat. This skill can grant an advantage in initiative or allow an immediate action that would normally take longer to perform.
Quick Draw.name: Quick Draw

Quill Pen.description: A large feather sharpened into a writing point.
Quill Pen.name: Quill Pen

Quiver.description: This is a container for arrows or quarrels; it is usually made of leather. A lesser-quality quiver is included in the basic cost of a load of ammunition, as noted on the Ammunition Table.
Quiver.name: Quiver

Raise Dead*.description:
This spell allows the cleric to raise any human, dwarf, halfling, or elf from the dead. The body must be present, and any missing parts will cause corresponding disabilities in the raised character.

Effect: An 8th-level cleric can raise a body that has been dead up to four days. Each level above 8th extends this limit by four additional days (e.g., a 10th-level cleric can raise bodies dead for up to twelve days).

The character is raised with 1 hit point and is weakened: unable to fight, cast spells, or move faster than half speed. These penalties last for two weeks of complete bed rest, which cannot be hastened by magical healing.

Undead Effect: When cast on an undead creature within range, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells with a -2 penalty or be destroyed. Vampires that fail the save retreat to their coffins in gaseous form. Against undead creatures stronger than vampires, the spell deals 3d10 damage (saving throw for half).
Raise Dead*.name: Raise Dead*
Raise Dead*.spellEffect: Raises one dead human or demihuman, or damages undead

Rapid Fire.description:
A successful Check enables a character to fire a bow twice instead of once. Each shot is made with a penalty of ‐3 to hit. The first arrow is fired according to which side wins initiative, the second arrow is always fired at the end of the round.

From GAZ13.
Rapid Fire.name: Rapid Fire

Ration, Iron.description: Preserved food for one person for one week. Includes items like dried meat, hardtack, and preserved fruits and vegetables. It lasts up to two months under normal conditions and one week in harsh conditions, such as dungeons.
Ration, Iron.name: Ration, Iron

Ration, Standard.description: Untreated food sufficient for one person for one week. It is prone to spoilage in damp environments, such as dungeons, and is best for overland travel.
Ration, Standard.name: Ration, Standard

Read Languages.description: This spell allows the caster to read, but not speak, any unknown languages, codes, or symbols—including treasure maps or secret scripts—for the spell’s duration.
Read Languages.name: Read Languages

Read Magic.description:
This spell allows the caster to read any magical words or runes, such as those found on scrolls or inscribed on items. It does not allow the caster to speak the words, only to read and understand them. A spellcaster cannot understand unfamiliar magical writings without using this spell.

Once a caster reads a scroll or rune with this spell, they can read or speak that magic again without using this spell. All spell books are written in magical words, and only their owners may read them without using this spell.
Read Magic.name: Read Magic

Remove Curse*.description:
This spell removes one curse from a character, item, or area. Some curses, especially those on magical items, may only be lifted temporarily. For permanent removal, a dispel evil spell or a remove curse cast by a higher-level caster may be required (at the DM's discretion).

The reverse of this spell, curse, imposes a penalty or misfortune on the target, with effects limited only by the caster's imagination. If the curse is too powerful, it may rebound on the caster (DM's discretion). Typical curses include a -4 penalty to attack rolls, a -2 penalty to saving throws, halving of a prime requisite, or a -4 penalty on others' reaction rolls. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the curse.
Remove Curse*.name: Remove Curse*

Remove Fear*.description:
When the spellcaster casts this spell and then touches any living creature, it will calm the creature and remove any fear. If the creature has been affected by a fear spell or effect that normally does not allow a saving throw, the remove fear spell can still be effective. If the spellcaster uses the spell on someone afflicted by a magical fear effect, the victim gets to make a saving throw vs. spells, with a bonus to the roll equal to the spellcaster's level of experience (up to a maximum bonus of +6). If the saving throw is successful, the victim's fear is dispelled. Regardless of the spellcaster's level or any bonuses, a roll of 1 will always fail.

The reversed form of the spell, cause fear, will make any one creature flee for two turns. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect. This reversed spell has a range of 120'.
Remove Fear*.name: Remove Fear*

Remove Quest*.description:
The reversed form of the quest spell, *Remove Quest* dispels an unwanted quest or removes a quest-related curse. The base chance of successfully removing the quest is 50%, modified by ±5% for each level difference between the caster of *Remove Quest* and the original caster of the quest.

For example, an 11th-level cleric attempting to remove a quest imposed by a 13th-level caster has a 40% chance of success, while a 36th-level cleric removing a quest cast by a 20th-level cleric has a 99% chance of success (capped to prevent automatic success).
Remove Quest*.name: Remove Quest*
Remove Quest*.spellEffect: Removes an unwanted quest or curse

Remove Traps.description: After detecting a trap, the character can attempt to disarm it safely. Success is based on a percentage determined by their level.
Remove Traps.name: Remove Traps

Resist Cold.description: When this spell is cast, all creatures within 30' of the spellcaster are protected from freezing temperatures without harm. Those affected also receive a +2 bonus to all saving throws against cold-based attacks. Additionally, any cold damage dealt to them is reduced by 1 point per die, with a minimum of 1 point of damage per die. The effect moves with the spellcaster.
Resist Cold.name: Resist Cold

Resist Fire.description: For the duration of this spell, the recipient is immune to damage from normal fire and heat. They also receive a +2 bonus to all saving throws against magical fire (such as dragon breath or fireball). Additionally, any damage taken from such magical fire is reduced by 1 point per die of damage, with each die dealing at least 1 point of damage. For red dragon breath, the damage is reduced by 1 point per Hit Die of the dragon, but never below 1 point per Hit Die.
Resist Fire.name: Resist Fire

Riding (choose type).description: This skill covers the ability to ride and control a specific type of mount, such as a horse, griffon, or dragon. The chosen type must be specified when the skill is selected. Riding involves managing the mount in various situations, including combat, hazardous terrain, and high-speed maneuvers. The skill can also be used to calm and handle a frightened or unruly mount.
Riding (choose type).name: Riding (choose type)

Ring of Protection +1.description: This ring improves the wearer's armor class by 1. It also has the effect of improving all saving throws by 1.
Ring of Protection +1.name: Ring of Protection +1

Ring of Strength +1.description: While worn, this ring increases the wearers strength ability score by 1.
Ring of Strength +1.name: Ring of Strength +1

Rope (50' length).description: A heavy climbing rope that can support up to three fully loaded humans, approximately 7,500 coins in total weight. It can be tied to an iron spike for climbing steep surfaces or used to tie up prisoners and pull open doors.
Rope (50' length).name: Rope (50' length)

Ruby.description: Ruby is a gemstone known for its deep red color and brilliance. It typically features a smooth, polished surface and a faceted appearance, enhancing its clarity and vibrant hue. Rubies are highly valued in jewelry for their rich color and elegant sparkle.
Ruby.name: Ruby

Sack, Large.description: A 2' x 4' burlap, cloth, or leather bag that can hold up to 600 coins. It is typically carried over a shoulder or tied onto a cart or saddle, making it useful for carrying large amounts of treasure or bulky items.
Sack, Large.name: Sack, Large

Sack, Small.description: A 1' x 2' cloth or leather bag that can hold up to 200 coins. It can be carried over the shoulder or tied onto a cart or saddle. Often used to store small items or treasure.
Sack, Small.name: Sack, Small

Saddle Bags (large).description:
Saddle bags are leather bags designed to fit over the back of a riding saddle and provide some storage on a ridden animal. The bags are tied to the saddle to prevent them from falling off. A person can throw them over their shoulder to make sure any valuables that are
in the saddlebags are not stolen while the rider is of their mount. The size is in relation to the size of the riding animal.

Weight held (pounds/coins)50/500
Volume held (cu. ft.)5
Saddle Bags (large).name: Saddle Bags (large)

Sanctify Ground.description: A cleric can sanctify an area, such as a shrine or graveyard, to prevent the entry of undead and demonic creatures. This ritual requires special materials and time, and its duration and effectiveness are determined by the cleric's level.
Sanctify Ground.name: Sanctify Ground

Sapphire.description: Sapphire is a gemstone known for its deep blue color and brilliance. It has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted appearance, showcasing its clarity and vibrant hue. Sapphires are highly prized in jewelry for their stunning color and elegant sparkle.
Sapphire.name: Sapphire

Scale Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates that have metal scales or studs sewn onto them for added protection. Scale mail gives a character an armor class of 6
Scale Mail.name: Scale Mail

Science (choose type).description: The character is an expert in one branch of scientific study, such as astronomy, geology, metallurgy, etc. This expertise allows the character to provide specialized knowledge and make expert judgments within that field. The player must indicate the specific branch of science their character has mastered. Characters may take this skill multiple times to represent expertise in different scientific disciplines.
Science (choose type).name: Science (choose type)

Scroll Case.description: An oiled leather tube with a cap. Not completely watertight.
Scroll Case.name: Scroll Case

Scroll of Stone to Flesh.description: This scroll contains the magic-user spell *Stone to Flesh*, which is a 6th-level spell. When read aloud, it can turn a statue or an amount of stone up to 10' x 10' x 10' into flesh. Commonly used to restore those petrified by effects like a gorgon’s breath. The reverse spell, *Flesh to Stone*, will transform a living creature into stone unless the target succeeds on a save versus petrification.
Scroll of Stone to Flesh.name: Scroll of Stone to Flesh

Set Spear vs. Charge.description: A halfling can set a spear against a charging opponent, dealing double damage if the attack hits.
Set Spear vs. Charge.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Shield.description:
This spell creates a magical barrier around the caster, less than an inch away from their body. It grants an AC of 2 against missiles and AC 4 against all other attacks. The barrier moves with the caster, and it does not interfere with the caster’s movements or attacks.

If a magic missile is shot at the caster, the caster can make a saving throw vs. spells. If successful, the missile is negated by the shield and has no effect.
Shield.name: Shield

Shipbuilding.description: This is the skill of designing and building ships. It allows a character to supervise the construction of professional-quality ships, whether made by muscle or by magic. Successful use of the skill lets characters evaluate ships they encounter to determine who built them and when.
Shipbuilding.name: Shipbuilding

Shovel.description: A shovel used for digging holes in the ground and whacking people upside the head.
Shovel.name: Shovel

Shrink Plants*.description: The reverse of *Growth of Plants*, this spell causes normal plants within the area of effect to shrink, becoming passable. It can be used to negate the effects of *Growth of Plants* but does not affect plant-like monsters such as treants.
Shrink Plants*.name: Shrink Plants*

Signaling (choose type).description: This skill allows the character to leave messages that can only be understood by another Signaling specialist of the same culture, trade guild, military force, or "school." The player must specify the type and culture of signals the character studies, such as military trumpet signals, naval flag signals, smoke signals, or drum signals.
Signaling (choose type).name: Signaling (choose type)

Silence 15' Radius.description: This spell creates an area of total silence within a 15' radius, making it impossible to converse or cast spells inside the affected area for the duration of the spell. Those within the sphere can still hear sounds from outside. If the spell is cast on a creature, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells. If the saving throw fails, the effect moves with the creature. If successful, the silence remains stationary, and the creature can leave the affected area.
Silence 15' Radius.name: Silence 15' Radius

Singing.description: The Singing skill enables a character to perform vocal music with skill and emotion. It is used in performances to entertain, in rituals to invoke magic, or in social situations to charm or persuade. A successful Singing check can captivate an audience, enhance the effects of other abilities, or even distract or charm creatures through melody and lyrics.
Singing.name: Singing

Sleep.description:
This spell puts 2-16 Hit Dice of creatures to sleep within a 40' square area. It affects creatures with 4+1 HD or less and does not work against undead or very large creatures, such as dragons. Creatures outside the area of effect are not affected.

Slapping, kicking, or shaking a sleeping creature will wake it. A single blow with an edged weapon can kill a sleeping creature, regardless of its hit points.

Your Dungeon Master will roll [[/r 2d8 #Sleep total hit dice affected]] to determine the total Hit Dice or experience levels of creatures affected by the spell. No saving throw is allowed.

The spell will put the targets to sleep for [[/r 4d4 #Sleep duration in turns]] turns.
Sleep.name: Sleep
Sleep.spellEffect: 2d8 Hit Dice of living creatures within a 40' square area

Sling.description: A sling is a long (4’ to 6’) leather cord with a pouch half way along. The wielder straps one end of the cord around their wrist and holds the other end in the same hand. They then place a lead pellet in the pouch and swing the cord over their head. At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.
Sling.name: Sling

Slow*.description:
The reversed version of *Haste*, *Slow* reduces the movement and attack speed of up to 24 creatures within a 60' diameter area to half their normal rate.

Effect: Slowed creatures move and attack at half speed but are otherwise unaffected, including spellcasting and magical device usage. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect.
Slow*.name: Slow*
Slow*.spellEffect: Up to 24 creatures move at half speed

Smash.description:
This is a Fighter Combat Option maneuver available to fighters and mystics starting at 9th level, and to demihumans at different experience levels (refer to their experience tables). When using this hand-to-hand maneuver, the character automatically loses initiative and takes a -5 penalty to their attack roll (but still applies their Strength and magic bonuses).

If the attack hits, the character adds their Strength bonus, magic bonuses, and their full Strength score to the weapon's normal damage.

For example, a fighter with Strength 17 (+2 to attack and damage) using a sword +2 (+2 to attack, 1d8 + 2 damage) would execute a smash as follows: the attack roll is made with a net penalty of -1 (+2 +2 -5). If successful, they roll 1d8 + 21 (17 + 2 + 2) for damage!
Smash.name: Smash

Snake Charm.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to charm a number of Hit Dice of snakes equal to their level, with no saving throw allowed. For example, a 5th-level spellcaster could charm one 5 HD snake, five 1 HD snakes, or any combination of snakes totaling 5 Hit Dice or less. The charmed snakes will rise up and sway, but will not attack unless provoked.

If the spell is cast on snakes that are attacking the spellcaster, the duration is [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Snake Charm duration in rounds]]. Otherwise, the spell lasts for [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Snake Charm duration in turns]]. Once the spell ends, the snakes return to their normal behavior, but they will not automatically be hostile unless provoked.
Snake Charm.name: Snake Charm
Snake Charm.spellEffect: Charms 1 HD of snakes per level of the caster

Snares.description: This is the skill of building traps to capture animals, monsters, and unwanted visitors. A successful skill roll means the trap functions properly. The DM can assign modifiers to the skill roll based on the time the character had to set up the trap, the availability of materials, etc.
Snares.name: Snares

Speak with Animals.description:
When casting this spell, the spellcaster must name one type of animal (such as wolves). For the duration of the spell, the spellcaster can communicate with all animals of that type within 30'; the effect moves with the caster.

The spell allows the caster to speak to any normal or giant forms of the named animal type, but only to one type at a time. The spell cannot be used to communicate with intelligent animals or fantastic creatures.

The animals typically react favorably (with a +2 bonus to reaction rolls) and may be persuaded to perform a favor for the spellcaster if the reaction roll is high enough. The animal must be capable of understanding and carrying out the request.
Speak with Animals.name: Speak with Animals

Speak with Plants.description:
This spell allows the caster to communicate with plants within a 30' radius, treating them as if they have intelligence. The caster may ask simple favors, such as making a path through dense undergrowth, which the plants will grant if able.

Effect: Enables communication with plant creatures, including plantlike monsters such as treants.
Speak with Plants.name: Speak with Plants

Speak with the Dead.description:
By means of this spell, a caster may ask three questions of a deceased spirit if the body is within range.

A caster of 6th or 7th level can contact recently deceased spirits (those dead up to 4 days). Casters of levels 8-14 have slightly more power (contacting spirits up to 4 months dead), and casters of levels 15-20 have even more (speaking with corpses up to 4 years dead). No time limits apply to casters of 21st level or greater.

The spirit will always reply in a tongue known to the caster, but can only offer knowledge of things up to the time of its death. If the spirit's alignment is the same as the caster's, it will provide clear and brief answers; however, if the alignments differ, the spirit may reply in riddles.
Speak with the Dead.name: Speak with the Dead

Spear.description: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.
Spear.name: Spear

Spear +1.description: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.
Spear +1.name: Spear +1

Spear +2.description: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.
Spear +2.name: Spear +2

Special Defenses.description: At 300,000 XP, halflings take half damage from spells and spell-like effects. At 2,100,000 XP, they take half damage from breath weapons. If a saving throw is successful, the damage is reduced to one-quarter.
Special Defenses.name: Special Defenses

Spell Research.description: A Magic-User can research and create new spells to add to their spellbook. This requires time, resources, and the approval of the Dungeon Master. The chance of success is based on the complexity of the spell and the magic-user’s level.
Spell Research.name: Spell Research

Spellbook.description: The spell book is a sizable, bulky item, approximately 2 feet square and 2–6 inches thick, weighing at least 20 pounds. It cannot fit inside any normal sack, regardless of size, but can be carried in a backpack or saddlebag. Written in magical script, the spell book can only be read by its owner unless another individual uses a read magic spell.
Spellbook.name: Spellbook

Spellbook, travelling.description:
A Spellbook is an essential feature of any Magic-User's kit. This is where their spells and formulae are stored, and is used to prepare for spellcasting.

A smaller, more portable option is the leather-bound Traveling spellbook. This book is typically about 10” x 6.5” in size with 64 pages. It can store up to 64 levels of spells. Either will fit into a backpack or satchel. In general, a Magic-Users' starting book is assumed to be a Traveling book, but a player may start with a Reference book if the GM allows it.

The initial spellbook of a Magic-User is given as a gift from their instructors.
Spellbook, travelling.name: Spellbook, travelling

Spellcasting.description: Magic-Users can memorize and cast arcane spells. The number and level of spells they can prepare is determined by their level. Spells must be learned and recorded in the magic-user’s spellbook before they can be cast.
Spellcasting.name: Spellcasting

Stakes (3) and Mallet.description: Three large (18”) wooden stakes and a wooden mallet, often used for destroying vampires or securing ropes and tents. They can also be used to pin down an opponent or object to the ground.
Stakes (3) and Mallet.name: Stakes (3) and Mallet

Stealth (choose terrain).description: The Stealth skill allows a character to move silently and remain unseen in a specific type of environment, such as forests, urban areas, or caves. The chosen terrain must be specified when the skill is selected. Characters with this skill can avoid detection, set up ambushes, or scout ahead without revealing their presence. The effectiveness of this skill may depend on the terrain's features and the character’s preparation.
Stealth (choose terrain).name: Stealth (choose terrain)

Sticks to Snakes.description:
This spell transforms [[/r 2d8 #sticks into snakes]] sticks into snakes, which may be poisonous (50% chance per snake). The snakes obey the caster's commands but will revert to sticks when slain or when the spell's duration ends.

Snake Stats: AC 6; HD 1; AT 1 bite; Dmg 1d4; MV 90' (30'); Save F1; ML 12; AL Neutral; SA poison (50% chance per snake to be poisonous).

Non-poisonous snakes grant 10 XP each, while poisonous ones grant 13 XP each.
Sticks to Snakes.name: Sticks to Snakes
Sticks to Snakes.spellEffect: Turns up to 16 sticks into snakes

Storytelling.description: The Storytelling skill allows a character to weave captivating tales that can entertain, inspire, or impart wisdom. This skill is used to recount legends, share news, or persuade others through narrative. A successful Storytelling check can captivate an audience, spread information effectively, or even sway public opinion through the power of a well-told story.
Storytelling.name: Storytelling

Striking.description:
This spell allows any one weapon to inflict 1d6 additional points of damage per attack (similar to a magical staff of striking). The weapon will inflict this extra damage with every successful blow for as long as the spell lasts. This bonus does not apply to attack rolls, but only to damage rolls.

If the caster casts this spell on a normal weapon, the weapon may then damage creatures which are normally affected only by magic weapons; the weapon will do 1d6 points of damage per strike (regardless of the normal damage of the weapon).
Striking.name: Striking

Stronghold Construction.description: At Name level, a halfling may build a stronghold, which will attract other halflings to settle there if constructed in a suitable location.
Stronghold Construction.name: Stronghold Construction

Suit Armor.description: This is a suit primarily composed of overlapping metal plates, with chain mail underneath. Also known as jousting plate, suit armor must be specially made to fit its owner—and is often worn by nobility as a status symbol as much as for protection. However, it does provide more protection than any other (non-magical) armor. Suit armor gives a character an armor class of 0, and also reduces all damage done to the character by area effect attacks (such as Fireball spells and dragon’s breath) by one point per die of damage. If the suit armor is magical, it reduces such damage by an additional point per two points of enhancement bonus. Unfortunately, since suit armor is designed for tourney use and parades where the wearer spends their time on horseback, it is very bulky and noisy when worn on foot. When on foot, someone wearing suit armor can he heard moving up to 120’ away, negating any chance of surprise; and only has a 1 in 6 chance per round of being able to stand unaided if knocked prone.
Suit Armor.name: Suit Armor

Summon Animals.description:
This spell allows the druid to summon any or all normal animals within 360'. Only normal, non-magical creatures of animal intelligence are affected, including mammals, reptiles, and amphibians. It does not affect insects, arthropods, humans, or demihumans.

Animal Types: The druid may summon specific types or every animal within range. The total Hit Dice of responding animals equals the druid’s level, with small creatures (frogs, mice, squirrels, small birds) treated as 1/10 HD each.

Behavior: Animals respond by coming at their fastest movement rate, understand the druid’s speech, and will assist the druid as able. If harmed, a summoned animal will usually flee, breaking the spell for that animal. If the druid is attacked as a summoned animal arrives, the animal will attack the druid’s opponent, fleeing only if it fails a morale check.

This spell can also be used to calm hostile animals encountered while adventuring.
Summon Animals.name: Summon Animals

Survival (choose terrain).description: This skill allows the character to find food, shelter, and water in a single type of terrain (e.g., desert, forest/jungle, mountain/hill, open sea, plains, arctic). The character can forage automatically in fertile areas and uses the skill roll to determine success in searching for resources in more challenging environments. When supporting others, the character receives a +1 penalty to the roll per additional person.
Survival (choose terrain).name: Survival (choose terrain)

Sword, Two-Handed.description:
This weapon, also called the great sword, is the largest type of sword. It is similar to the normal sword (above) but much longer, usually being 4 1/2' to 6 1/2' long.

This sword is a two-handed weapon; the wielder of the weapon may not use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters not using a two-handed weapon. Halflings and small nonhumans such as goblins cannot use this weapon.
Sword, Two-Handed.name: Sword, Two-Handed

Telekinesis.description:
This spell allows the caster to move a creature or object by sheer concentration. The weight of the object can be up to 200 cn (20 lbs) per caster level. For example, a 10th-level caster could move an object up to 2,000 cn (200 lbs).

The object can be moved in any direction at a rate of up to 20' per round. The caster must concentrate, and the movement stops if concentration is broken.

Saving Throws: An unwilling creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being moved. If an item is being held, the holder may make a saving throw with a -2 penalty. For items carried but not held, the owner may attempt to grab it with a saving throw at a -5 penalty.
Telekinesis.name: Telekinesis
Telekinesis.spellEffect: 200 cn of weight per level of caster

Teleport.description:
This spell instantly transports the caster or another creature within 10' to any unoccupied destination on the same plane. Distance does not matter, and the recipient arrives at the destination with all carried equipment. An unwilling target can make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid teleportation.

Restrictions on Destination: The caster cannot deliberately teleport to an occupied space, and must choose a solid surface for arrival (such as ground level or a building top), not mid-air.

Teleportation Accuracy: Teleporting carries a risk of inaccuracy based on the caster’s familiarity with the location. Familiarity levels—Casual, General, and Exact—impact the chance of success. The DM rolls d% and consults the table below.

Knowledge of DestinationSuccessToo HighToo Low
Casual (visited once or twice, or by description)01-5051-7576-00
General (visited often or studied magically)01-8081-9091-00
Exact (detailed personal study)01-9596-9900

Teleport Results:

  • Success: The recipient arrives at the chosen location.
  • Too High: The recipient arrives 1d10 x 10' above the destination, taking 1d6 points of damage per 10' fallen, unless flying or levitating.
  • Too Low: The recipient arrives 1d10 x 10' below the destination. Teleporting into solid objects results in instant death unless an open area (e.g., a cave) exists there, at the DM's discretion.
Teleport.name: Teleport

Thief.description:
A thief is a human adventurer specializing in stealth, agility, and subterfuge. They excel in tasks like lockpicking, trap disarming, and infiltration, relying on dexterity and cunning to navigate challenges rather than brute force.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Dexterity, granting a 5% experience bonus for scores of 13–15 and 10% for 16 or higher.
  • Combat Skills: Thieves may use any one-handed melee weapon and missile weapons but cannot wield two-handed weapons. They are restricted to leather armor and cannot use shields.
  • Hit Dice: Thieves roll a d4 for hit points per level until 9th level, after which they gain 2 hit points per level.

  • Special Abilities:

    • Open Locks, Find and Remove Traps, Climb Walls, Move Silently, Hide in Shadows, Pick Pockets, and Hear Noise.
    • At 4th level, they can read non-magical languages (80% chance).
    • At 10th level, they can cast magic-user spells from scrolls (10% chance of backfire).
    • Backstabbing: A thief gains +4 to attack rolls when unnoticed and deals double damage on a successful hit.

Advancement:

  • At 9th level, a thief becomes a "Master Thief" and may establish a hideout, such as a fortified house or network of secret chambers.
  • The hideout attracts 2d6 1st-level apprentice thieves who seek training under the master thief.
  • A thief may rise in the ranks of the Thieves' Guild, eventually leading a branch or even the guild itself.

Stronghold Options:

  • Thieves often rely on the local Thieves' Guild for resources when establishing a hideout. The guild may help them become a guildmaster or expand into new territories.
  • If the thief remains unaffiliated, they are considered a rogue, maintaining guild membership for support but operating independently.

Thieves thrive on their agility, sharp wits, and resourcefulness, providing unique skills to adventuring parties while navigating the fine line between heroics and illicit activity.
Thief.name: Thief

Thieves' Tools.description: Required for picking locks, these items are usable only by thieves. A typical set includes fine wire, various lockpicks, etc.
Thieves' Tools.name: Thieves' Tools

Tinder Box.description: A small box containing flint, steel, and tinder (wood shavings). Used to start fires for camp or torches. Under dry conditions, a fire starts on a roll of 1 or 2 on a d6. May be tried once per round.
Tinder Box.name: Tinder Box

Topaz.description: Topaz is a gemstone that can appear in golden-yellow or light blue colors. It has a smooth, polished surface with a brilliant, faceted appearance, showcasing its clarity and reflective properties. Topaz is prized for its vibrant hue and sparkling brilliance, making it a popular choice in jewelry.
Topaz.name: Topaz

Torch.description: This is any 1' to 2' long piece of wood, its head sometimes covered with an inflammable substance such as pitch. It casts light in a 30' radius and burns for one hour (six turns). See the description from the Weapons Table for information on using a torch as a weapon; clerics can use it as a weapon.
Torch.name: Torch

Torch (weapon).description: This is just a regular torch, but wielded as a weapon. If the torch is unlit, then it only does 1d2 damage. The torch is considered to be a flaming club, and is covered under the club weapon mastery.
Torch (weapon).name: Torch (weapon)

Tracking.description: The character can follow tracks. The DM may adjust the chance of success depending on the circumstances such as age of the tracks, type of terrain, number of tracks being followed, and other factors. A successful skill check indicates the character has successfully followed the tracks to their destination or the next significant point.
Tracking.name: Tracking

Trident.description: A trident is a short (4’ to 6’) spear which is split at the end into three tines, like a fork. Each tine is usually barbed. A trident is used in one hand either in melee or as a thrown weapon, and is often used as a fishing spear, since the barbs on the points can lift the fish out of the water when the trident is withdrawn.
Trident.name: Trident

Truesight.description:
With *Truesight*, the cleric gains the ability to see all things as they truly are within a 120' radius. The spell reveals all hidden, invisible, and ethereal objects or creatures, functioning as the *detect invisible* spell.

Additionally, the cleric perceives any secret doors, and can see through any form of disguise, polymorph, or other alterations. Deception is impossible. The spell also reveals creatures' alignments, experience, and power levels.
Truesight.name: Truesight
Truesight.spellEffect: Reveals true forms of all things within 120'

Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D#: Automatic destroy; destroys 4d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
Turn Undead.name: Turn Undead

Turn Undead (Paladin/Avenger).description:
Rule: A paladin or an avenger can turn undead, as if he were a cleric of one-third his actual experience level (round all fractions down).

Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Paladins/Avengers have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the paladin/avenger can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the paladin/avenger simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the paladin/avenger succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the paladin/avenger again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
Turn Undead (Paladin/Avenger).name: Turn Undead (Paladin/Avenger)

Turquoise.description: Turquoise is a vibrant blue-green gemstone often featuring natural veining or matrix patterns. It has a smooth, polished surface and is highly valued for its striking color and unique texture, making it popular in jewelry and decorative arts.
Turquoise.name: Turquoise

Unarmed Strike.name: Unarmed Strike

Use Magic Items.description: Magic-Users can utilize various magical items, such as wands, staves, and scrolls, that are typically unavailable to non-spellcasting classes. This ability allows them to activate magical effects stored within these items.
Use Magic Items.name: Use Magic Items

Use of Blessed Items.description: Clerics can use blessed items such as scrolls with cleric spells and other religious artifacts. This ability allows them to invoke the power of their deity through these items.
Use of Blessed Items.name: Use of Blessed Items

Use of Holy Water.description: Clerics can create and use holy water. Holy water is a special substance that harms undead creatures, dealing 1d8 damage on a successful hit when thrown. It is created by performing a blessing ritual on pure water.
Use of Holy Water.name: Use of Holy Water

Ventriloquism.description: This spell allows the caster to make their voice seem to come from another location within range, such as a statue, animal, or a dark corner. The "source" of the voice must be within the spell's range.
Ventriloquism.name: Ventriloquism

Veterinary Healing.description:
This skill is similar to the Healing skill but pertains to creatures other than humans or demihumans, such as monsters, animals, and other nonhuman creatures. A successful skill roll allows the character to restore [[/r 1d3 #Veterinary Healing (Hit Points Restored)]] hit points to a creature. This skill can be taken in two ways:

  • General Veterinary Healing: A +1 penalty applies for each type of creature the character treats.
  • Specialized Veterinary Healing: Pertains to one specific class of creatures (e.g., equines), with no penalty for that class but a +2 penalty for all others.

A character with this skill who attempts to treat humans or demihumans must roll with a +3 penalty.
Veterinary Healing.name: Veterinary Healing

Vial (glass).description: A small, clear glass vial commonly used to store liquids, potions, or other substances. It is fragile and can easily break if dropped or struck. This vial can hold up to 8 ounces of liquid.
Vial (glass).name: Vial (glass)

Wall of Fire.description:
This spell creates a thin, vertical wall of fire in any shape or dimension, totaling 1,200 square feet (e.g., 10' x 120', 20' x 60', 30' x 40'). The wall is opaque and blocks sight, and it cannot be created in a space already occupied by another object.

Duration: The wall remains as long as the caster concentrates on it without moving.

Breaking Through: Creatures with less than 4 Hit Dice cannot pass through the wall. Creatures with 4 HD or more may pass through, taking 1d6 fire damage in the process. Undead and cold-using creatures (e.g., white dragons, frost giants) each take double damage (2d6) when breaking through.
Wall of Fire.name: Wall of Fire

Wall of Ice.description:
This spell creates a thin, opaque wall of ice covering up to 1,200 square feet (e.g., 10' x 120' or 30' x 40'). The caster chooses the shape, but the wall must rest on the ground or similar support and cannot overlap with other objects.

Breaking Through: Creatures with less than 4 Hit Dice cannot break through the wall. Creatures with 4 HD or more can break through, taking 1d6 damage in the process. Fire-type creatures suffer double damage (2d6) when breaking through.
Wall of Ice.name: Wall of Ice

Wall of Stone.description:
This spell creates a vertical stone wall, 2' thick. The caster selects the wall’s dimensions and shape, up to a maximum area of 500 square feet (e.g., 10' x 50', 20' x 25'). The entire wall must be within 60' of the caster.

Placement and Durability: The wall must be created on the ground or a similar support and cannot occupy a space that already contains another object. The wall lasts until it is either dispelled or physically broken.

Falling Wall: If the wall topples, it causes 10d10 damage to whatever it hits and then shatters.
Wall of Stone.name: Wall of Stone

Warp Wood.description:
This spell causes wooden weapons to bend and become useless. It affects one arrow for each level of the caster. A spear, javelin, or magical wand counts as two arrows, and a club, bow, or staff counts as four.

The spell does not affect other wooden items. If a magical wooden item is targeted, the wielder may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect. Items carried but not held get no saving throw. Magical items with "pluses" might not be affected, with a 10% chance per "plus" (for example, an arrow +1 has a 10% chance to be unaffected).
Warp Wood.name: Warp Wood

Water Breathing.description: This spell enables the recipient to breathe underwater at any depth for one full day. It does not affect movement underwater and does not interfere with breathing air.
Water Breathing.name: Water Breathing

Waterskin/Wineskin.description: A flexible container made of leather or a preserved animal bladder, with a capacity of two quarts. When filled, it has an encumbrance of 30 coins; when empty, 5 coins. A normal-sized person drinks about 2qts of water per day.
Waterskin/Wineskin.name: Waterskin/Wineskin

Web.description:
This spell conjures a thick, sticky web that fills the affected area. The web traps creatures, restricting movement and blocking passage. Giants or creatures with great strength can break through the web in 2 rounds, while a human of average strength will take [[/r 2d4 #Escape Time in Turns]] turns to break free.

Flames, such as from a torch, will burn away the web in 2 rounds, dealing [[/r 1d6 #Fire Damage]] damage to anyone caught in it. Magical items like gauntlets of ogre power reduce escape time to 4 rounds.
Web.name: Web

Whip (10').description:
This weapon consists of a long, braided leather strap with a handle, ranging in length from 5 to 30 feet. It is a hand-to-hand weapon capable of causing damage (1d2 points) or entangling opponents. Before each combat round, the wielder must declare whether they are attempting to deal damage or entangle. In either case, a normal attack roll is required.

If the attack hits, the whip either deals 1d2 points of damage or, if attempting to entangle, forces the target to make a saving throw vs. death ray, potentially with a bonus. The saving throw bonus and the outcome of the entangling attempt are determined using the Weapon Special Effects Table. On a failed saving throw, the target suffers one of the following effects:

  • Entangle: The victim is unable to attack, cast spells, or move until they succeed on a saving throw.
  • Slow: The victim's movement and attack rates are halved, and they cannot cast spells.
  • Delay: The victim automatically loses initiative in the next round.

This weapon is primarily a tactical tool and is often used by thieves or other characters who prefer to support front-line fighters without directly engaging in melee combat.

A whip can only entangle creatures with a solid form; it has no entangling effect on wraiths, spectres, ethereal creatures, or monsters composed of water (e.g., water elementals). However, these beings still take normal damage from the whip. (Note that a regular whip cannot harm creatures that require magical weapons to hit; such cases require a magical whip.)
Whip (10').name: Whip (10')

Wine.description: A quart of common wine. It does not include a container and is often carried in a wineskin. Useful for social occasions or in some cases, as a barter item.
Wine.name: Wine

Wizard Eye.description:
This spell creates an invisible eye, through which the caster can see. The eye is the size of a normal eye and grants the caster infravision with a range of 60'.

Movement: The wizard eye floats through the air at a speed of up to 120' per turn but cannot pass through solid objects. It cannot move further than 240' from the caster.

Concentration: The caster must concentrate without moving to see through the eye, directing its movement and observing through it for the spell’s duration.
Wizard Eye.name: Wizard Eye

Wizard Lock.description:
This spell functions as a stronger version of the hold portal spell. It can be used on any portal or lock, not just doors, and it remains in effect indefinitely unless dispelled by magic.

A knock spell can bypass the wizard lock temporarily. The caster who placed the lock, as well as any spellcaster or creature with three or more levels (or Hit Dice) greater than the caster, can open the locked portal without removing the spell. Once the portal is closed again, the lock re-engages.
Wizard Lock.name: Wizard Lock

Wolfsbane.description: Sold dried or fresh in single sprigs, this herb is used to drive off lycanthropes, who cannot abide its presence. The sprig must be swung or thrown as a weapon to be effective.
Wolfsbane.name: Wolfsbane

Woodform.description:
This spell creates a mass of wood, up to 1,000 cubic feet in volume, which may be arranged in any shape the caster desires (e.g., 10' x 10' x 10' block, 25' x 20' x 2' wall).

Casting Time: Varies by design complexity. Simple shapes, like a wall, take 1 round. A staircase may take 10 rounds (1 turn), while more complex designs, like a ship keel, can take up to 12 turns (2 hours). The DM decides casting time for complex designs.

Object Properties: The wood must be created as a single piece with no moving parts. Once created, the wood is permanent, non-dispellable, and cannot be modified by further woodform spells unless cast by the original caster within two hours to make refinements. The caster may create wood with rough edges, which another woodform can later seamlessly join to the first.

The wood must rest on solid ground or a similar support, and cannot occupy a space already containing an object. The type of wood can be chosen by the caster but may be limited by the DM, especially for exotic or magical woods.

Durability: The wood lasts until destroyed by damage (e.g., burning, breaking) or spells like *Disintegrate*. It has an AC of -4 (6) and 60 hit points per 1' thickness, based on the Fortifications Table (page 137). Most exterior wooden walls are 8" thick, giving them 40 hit points.
Woodform.name: Woodform

Wrestling.description:
The Wrestling skill enables a character to grapple, pin, or otherwise subdue opponents using hand-to-hand combat techniques. A successful skill roll improves the character's Wrestling Rating (WR), providing a +1 bonus per skill level.

In wrestling combat, a character with Wrestling skill gains a bonus on their Wrestling Rating for initiating or resisting grapples and pins. The higher the skill level, the more effective the character becomes, providing a cumulative +1 to WR per level (e.g., Wrestling +1 skill gives +2 WR).

This skill is especially useful in situations where the character needs to subdue an opponent without lethal force, or in confined spaces where weapons are impractical. Mastery in Wrestling also allows for improved control over an opponent’s movements, reducing their ability to counterattack or escape.
Wrestling.name: Wrestling
